title: Meghan Harry flew home private jet owned Guthy Renker
story: Share this article On Saturday the Duke and Duchess of Sussex were spotted disembarking from Guthy-Renker's Dassault Falcon 2000LX private jet in their home town of Santa Barbara on Saturday after a three-day VIP tour of New York City.According to Federal Aviation Administration records, the luxury 10-seat aircraft is owned by Guthy-Renker company GRP Aviation LLC, but when the firm is not using its jet it rents it out to a private jet charter service, Clay Lacy.The Falcon costs around $115,000 for a LA-Big Apple round trip according to Clay Lacy flight quotes for next month.Prices at the charter jet firm ranged from $61,875 for a Bombardier Challenger 300 to $118,736 for a Beechcraft Hawker 850XP. The Falcon was their second most expensive jet.But a customer service agent at Clay Lacy told DailyMail.com that they had no charter flights on record for the Falcon on Saturday – meaning Harry and Meghan's flight was provided by the airplane's owner Guthy-Renker, not the charter service.The firm's two founders, Bill Guthy and Greg Renker, both have properties in Carpinteria near the Sussexes' mansion in Santa Barbara, and are worth over $500million each.     Cindy Crawford and the Meaningful Beauty Infomercial (FULL) - YouTube

title: Mother left motorcyclist lying middle road handed 12 month driving ban
story: Share this article The Middlesbrough court heard how the motorcyclist was 'left lying on the floor' and was 'very worried about lorries coming towards him' as he was wearing dark clothing.Ms Butt told how the victim felt that he was 'lucky a car or lorry didn't drive over him'.He was taken to James Cook University Hospital by the ambulance service by 'sheer luck' after a car, with two nurses, stopped at the scene.The victim remained in hospital for two weeks after suffering major injuries including a dislocated hip, multiple fractures in his wrist as well as a number of small injuries.He required surgery to repair his hip and wrist - and is now waiting to find out if he needs a hip replacement.The prosecutor said he is still 'suffering a lot of pain' and has restricted mobility since the smash.The victim is also having 'flashbacks' and 'recalls flying through the air' and was lucky he wasn't 'struck by a lorry and killed'.Ms Butt added that Ms Soakell, previously from Easington lane, Houghton-le-Spring, has no previous convictions and stated the Crown Prosecution Service would not be applying for compensation as it is being dealt with by insurance companies.Paul McAlindon, mitigating, told how Ms Soakell had a witness to 'support her account' but they were awaiting covid-19 test results on the day of trial and the trial went ahead in their absence.He described the expecting mother as a 'young lady who has never been in trouble before' and has 'lost her good character'.Mr McAlindon told the district judge how the defendant is a full-time community carer, covering the whole of the Durham area, and has worked throughout the pandemic.The 'busy young woman' is also due to give birth in January.The defence solicitor stated that Ms Soakell's driving licence is 'essential' for her job and asked for her licence to be endorsed with points, rather than a disqualification, so she can continue to work.Mr McAlindon said it is a 'horrendous offence' but stated that Ms Soakell is at 'low risk of reoffending'.District Judge Marie Mallon said the motorcyclist was 'exceedingly lucky' and 'far worse could have arisen'.She handed Ms Soakell a 20 week jail sentence, suspended for 18 months.

title: When ministers met road groups fix shortage tanker drivers leak sparked panic Mail reveals
story: Share this article I’m told that suspicions were heightened by the fact Duncan Buchanan, the RHA executive who was on the fateful Zoom call, made almost identical remarks during that discussion as the ‘lines’ that were briefed to ITV. Both he and Mr McKenzie, a former BBC journalist, have therefore found themselves thrown into the firing line.Grant Shapps, in an interview with Sky News last weekend, made the allegation in person: ‘There was a meeting which took place about ten days ago, a private meeting in which one of the haulage associations decided to leak the details to media,’ he said.In response to the claims, the RHA has issued a vigorous denial that McKenzie was responsible. Insiders there believe they are being scapegoated in order to shift public blame away from incompetent ministers and civil servants.‘Firstly, Rod McKenzie was not in the meeting where the BP issue was discussed,’ the RHA says. ‘Secondly, he is not the source of the leak. The first he heard of the comments was when journalists rang him asking for comment after the ITV News story had been broadcast.‘He was not, as the government source claimed, “aware of the comments” and certainly did not “weaponise” them in subsequent TV interviews. Indeed, he repeatedly stressed the need not to panic-buy and that there were adequate fuel stocks.‘It is also completely untrue to say that the “RHA leaks every meeting we have with them”. The RHA believes this disgraceful attack on a member of its staff is an attempt to ert attention away from their recent handling of the driver shortage crisis.’Buchanan has also denied responsibility for the leak.‘We have a huge degree of confidence that the RHA is to blame,’ says a senior government source. ‘Because the investigation is for now a Cabinet Office thing rather than a full public inquiry, we can’t at this stage compel them to come and give evidence, and we also can’t get the suspects to hand over their phones. But we aren’t ruling that out, so we assume they will co-operate fully.’Doubtless, they will. For a nation of motorists who bore the brunt of this week’s surreal and entirely unnecessary fuel crisis surely deserve a proper explanation.

title: Motorists followed truck carrying mortar believing fuel tanker
story: Share this article 'When I eventually turned left into a road that would take me to the site entrance, all these cars turned left with me.'Mr Anderson said: 'The man at the front wound down his window and asked me which petrol station I was going to.' He told the BBC: 'When I said I wasn't, he asked me Why not? and when I said I wasn't carrying petrol, he actually said You could have stopped and told us you weren't a petrol tanker.'I couldn't believe it... I just went full McEnroe and said You cannot be serious!One of the motorists then asked Mr Anderson if he had any idea where the nearest filling station was. Mr Anderson revealed why it isn't wise to follow a fuel tanker. He added: 'My cargo isn't dangerous but if they are following a petrol tanker, their training is to call the police if they think they're being followed.'People need to stop and think... driving a tanker, no matter what the product, is quite a pressurised job, so following them puts extra pressure on drivers already under pressure without having to worry about absolute morons.'Fuel supplies: Mortar tanker tailed by drivers looking for petrol - BBC News

title: covid 19 vaccine tracker how many people have been inoculated in ireland
story: It has been over a year since the first case of Covid-19 was confirmed in the Republic of Ireland. Since then, over 300,000 people have been diagnosed in the State, and over 5,000 people have died.Globally, over 200 million people have been diagnosed and over 4&nbspmillion have died since the virus was first identified in China in December 2019.Four of these have been authorised for use in the EU - one from AstraZeneca, one from BioNTech-Pfizer, one from Moderna and another from Johnson &amp Johnson (Janssen).The EU has put in place purchase agreements with Sanofi-GSK&nbspand Curevac, and&nbsphas concluded exploratory talks with two other vaccine producers - Novavax and Valneva.Ireland, along with all other EU member states, will get a proportional amount of every vaccine that is approved for use by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) according to its population.But how do these other vaccines work, and when will they be approved for use here? Have there been any reported side effects? And when can you expect to receive a vaccine?The  Vaccine Tracker will be updated daily as the country embarks on the largest inoculation programme in the history of the State.Storage: Must be kept in a freezer at - 70°C.EMA approval: Granted on December 21st.Overview: Developed by New York-based Pfizer and German company BioNTech this vaccine has a brand name of Comirnaty. It uses messenger RNA (mRNA) technology, which has instructions for producing a protein from Sars-CoV-2, the virus that causes Covid-19. The person’s immune system recognises this protein as foreign and produces antibodies and activates T-cells (white blood cells) to attack it, giving them immunity. The vaccine will last for six months when stored at -70C, and five days when stored at between 2 and 8 degrees Celsius. The EU has approved the withdrawal of six doses from each vial.Side effects: Common side effects (occurring in more than 1 in 10 people) included pain and swelling at the injection site, tiredness, headache, muscle and joint pain, chills and fever. Severe allergic reactions occurred in a very small number of cases.How many will Ireland get? 546,000 in April, 738,000 in May and&nbsp844,000 doses in June, with 5.4 million doses in total expected by the end of 2021.Storage: Must be kept in a freezer at - 20°C.EMA approval: Granted on January 6th.Overview: Developed by Boston-based company Moderna, this vaccine is manufactured for EU states at partner plants in Switzerland, France and Spain before being distributed across the continent. Like the Pfizer BioNTech vaccine, it uses mRNA technology to produce a Sars-CoV-2 protein, which the body then attacks to give immunity. It will last for up to six months when stored at - 20°C. The first Moderna vaccine was given in Ireland on January 16th.Side effects: Common side effects (occurring in more than 1 in 10 people) included pain and swelling at the injection site, tiredness, chills, fever, swollen or tender lymph nodes under the arm, headache, muscle and joint pain, nausea and vomiting. Less common was redness, hives and rash at the injection site. Severe allergic reactions occurred in a very small number of cases.How many will Ireland get? 383,000 by June and 870,000 doses by the end of 2021.How many have been vaccinated here?Dose: Two doses, between 4 and 12 weeks apartEMA approval: Granted on January 29th.Overview: The OxfordAstraZeneca vaccine (also known as Vaxzevria) was thought of as a potential game-changer because it can be transported and stored at 2 degrees to 8 degrees for up to six months, making it much easier to move around and administer. It is also much cheaper, costing about $3-4 per shot, compared with $20 for the PfizerBioNTech jab, with the former being made on a not-for-profit basis for the duration of the pandemic.It is based on a harmless chimp cold virus that cannot grow inside human cells. Scientists have tweaked this virus so that it carries genetic material containing the instructions for a protein of the coronavirus. Once the vaccine has been administered, our bodies produce the coronavirus protein, triggering an immune response.During the trial, a dosing error led to the serendipitous finding that when clinical trial participants were given half a dose followed by a full dose, the vaccine had a higher efficacy than when participants were given two full doses, with 90 per cent efficacy in the former case and 62 per cent efficacy in the latter. This led AstraZeneca to announce in November a new global trial of the vaccine with the half dosefull dose regime.In January, a bitter row broke out between the European Union and AstraZeneca after the pharmaceutical company drastically revised downwards the number of doses it could deliver the bloc.&nbspWhile the EMA approved the use of this vaccine for all ages, doubt was cast over its efficacy in the over 65s due to the lack of data from Astrazeneca’s clinical trials in this cohort. As a result, Germany, Austria, Sweden, Poland and Belgium have opted not to approve this product for their older population.Following suit, Ireland has also decided to use the Pfizer or Moderna vaccine for the over 70s where possible, not the AstraZeneca jab.It would not be the first time this jab led to a&nbspsignificant reorganisation of our vaccination plans.Reports of serious blood clots, mostly in women aged under 60, led the&nbspNational Immunisation Advisory Committee (Niac) to first defer the use of the vaccine on March 14th, before resuming it's use on March 20th.However, on April 12th, Niac&nbsprecommended that AstraZeneca should not be given to people aged under 60, once again leading to a reorganisation of the rollout. This was revised to people aged over 50 on April 27th. On June 28th, Niac revised its advice again and said the vaccine could be given&nbspto people aged under 40, although the mRNA shots were preferable for that age group.How many will Ireland get?&nbspLatest projections are 224,000 in April, 262,000 in May and 327,000 in JuneStorage: Lasts for up to two years frozen at –20° C, and up to three months refrigerated at 2-8° C.EMA approval: Approved on March 11th.Overview: The EMA started a rolling review of this single dose vaccine from Janssen, the Belgium-based subsidiary of Johnson &amp Johnson on December 1st.On January 29th the company announced the results of its Phase 3 trial: the vaccine had an efficacy of 72 per cent in the United States, 66 per cent in Latin America, and 57 per cent in South Africa.This vaccine uses double-stranded DNA to deliver a protein from the SARS-CoV-2 virus into the body, thereby creating immunity. It is different from others on the market in that it requires just one injection. The EU has agreed an initial contract for 200 million doses, with an option to buy 200 million more.On February 16th the company applied to the EMA for&nbspseeking authorisation for its single-dose vaccine, and it was approved on March 11th.However, on April 13th the company paused deliveries of its vaccine in Europe pending an investigation of rare blood clot cases that have halted its rollout in the US. The blood clotting conditions reported in recipients of the Johnson &amp Johnson vaccine in the US are the same rare condition linked to the AstraZeneca vaccine.On April 20th, the EMA's review of these issues found a possible link to very rare cases of unusual blood clots with low blood platelets, and agreed a warning should be included in the product information.&nbspHowever, it concluded&nbspthe overall benefits of the vaccine&nbspin preventing Covid-19 outweigh the risks of side effects, and so Janssen announced it would resume deliveries to the EU. In Ireland,&nbspNiac initially recommended that the jab be used only for people over the age of 50, but this was revised to include the under 40s on June 28th. Those aged 18-34 can apply to get the Janssen vaccine at pharmacies around the country.How many will Ireland get?&nbsp2.2 million doses in total,&nbsp600,000 between April and June.Storage: Stable at 2°C to 8°C.Overview: US company Novavax has developed a Covid-19 vaccine which stimulates an immune response by delivering spike proteins into the body. These spike-proteins are grown and harvested from insects. Similar technology is used in the production of vaccines for influenza and HPV. The European Commission has concluded exploratory talks with Novavax with a view to purchasing up to 200 million doses. The EMA began a rolling review of the vaccine on February 3rd.Overview: In September the EU signed a deal to purchase 300 million doses of this vaccine. It is based on the same technology as one of Sanofi’s seasonal influenza vaccines - more conventional than the mRNA used by Pfizer and Moderna - and it was thought it could play a big role in ending the pandemic. However, despite positive results from Phase 1 trials, news came in December that Phase 2 trial results showed an insufficient immune response in older adults. Phase III studies were expected to start in December, but the companies now plan to begin a phase 2b study in February with a different formulation of the vaccine. Even if their new formulation is successful, they do not expect the vaccine to be available until the end of 2021.Storage: Will last for at least 3 months at 2-8°C.Overview: The German company CureVac began its final Phase 3 trials in December, with results expected in the first quarter of 2021. It uses the same mRNA technology as the Moderna and Pfizer vaccines, but can be kept at normal refrigerator temperatures. The company has signed a deal with the EU to supply 405 million doses, pending regulatory approval.The EMA began a rolling review of the vaccine on February 12th.Storage: Stable at 2°C to 8°C.Overview: Valneva is a French company which has created a Covid-19 vaccine based on their Japanese encephalitis vaccine. It delivers a chemically inactivated coronavirus and uses an adjuvant (immunity booster) to create immunity. It entered clinical trials in December and reported positive results from these initial phase 1 and 2 trial in&nbspApril 2021, while announcing it was entering&nbspphase 3 trials on 4,000 people.On January 12th the European Commission concluded exploratory talks with the company for the supply of 30 million doses, with the option to buy a further 30 million.When might you be vaccinated?Over 80 per cent&nbspof people in Ireland aged over 18 are now fully vaccinated, with over 90 per cent in receipt of at least one dose. Anyone over the age of 12 can&nbsp now register for a vaccine. If you have not yet received&nbspyour vaccine&nbspyou can visit the HSE site here&nbspto register.&nbspEverything you need to know about the Covid-19 outbreak

title: popular culture portrayal does michael collins a great disservice
story: The ‘enormous charisma and impact of Michael Collins remains undeniable’, Taoiseach Micheál Martin. Photograph: Hulton ArchiveThe portrayal of Michael Collins in popular culture is “doing him a great disservice,” the Taoiseach Micheál Martin has suggested. Mr Martin, a historian before he became a politician, said the “enormous charisma and impact of Michael Collins remains undeniable”, but he was a more complex man than often portrayed. He would have rejected a presentation that put his personality before the ideas and movements he participated in. Speaking at a conference in University College Cork (UCC) on Saturday, marking the centenary of the Anglo-Irish Treaty, Mr Martin said when he looked up from his desk to find portraits of both Michael Collins and Éamon de Valera staring back at him. “I can’t but reflect on the fact that neither would be comfortable with the popular view which has often neglected to tell us how long and how successfully they worked together before the final Treaty negotiations,” he said. “Neither would support the idea that the enormous contribution of the other to the success of the War of Independence was overrated. They would have understand that they both operated in the year after the Truce with forces they could not fully control.” The Civil War was not inevitable, Mr Martin suggested, and “the sheer number of times that stopped the drift to conflict was remarkable”. Mr Martin described Arthur Griffith, the leader of the Irish delegation that negotiated and signed the Anglo-Irish Treaty, as a man who was often overlooked. “He was not just a major personality at the time, he was a relentless propagandist of the cause of Irish self-determination. His contribution was vital.” Mr Martin told the conference Ireland has developed an approach to commemorating the past which shown a “shared pride and a challenging reflection on our past”. Mr Martin said he took pride in the fact that, while other countries are “reverting to an inward looking and exclusionary nationalism, we have shown respect for the complexity of the past. “In marking the centenary of the Treaty I feel there is a lot of wisdom to be found in the guidance of the expert advisory group on commemorations where the State’s task is to encourage a reflective and reconciliatory tone that recognises that neither side had a monopoly of either atrocity or virtue.” Bringing the British to the negotiating table in 1921 was a “dramatic achievement” given the disparity of strength between the biggest empire in the world at the time and the IRA which lacked the military means that other independence movements had developed, he stated. However, the independence movement had the “broad support of the majority of the people” which the British side did not have. Mr Martin said the failure to expand the franchise in the June 1922 general election to include all women was a “shameful episode that set women back many decades”. The 1922 Irish constitution envisaged that women should be able to vote on an equal basis with men, but the Provisional Government at the time pleaded that there was not time to update the electoral register. “There is simply no doubt that the Treaty debates and its aftermath saw rampant misogyny in the service of belittling and marginalising the voices of women,” Mr Martin added. “Because of their predominance on the anti-Treaty side, women were often portrayed as hysterical and unthinking with no attempt to reflect their central role in the success and legitimacy of the Irish revolution.” The Taoiseach suggested that the centrist nature of Irish politics meant that the extremes of politics in Europe in the 20th century did not happen in Ireland. title: revised 165bn national infrastructure plan to include funding for extra roads
story: Locals in Ardee are concerned a new bypass of the town built on Ardee bog will have a devastating impact on local wildlife and may exasperate flooding in the area.  Video: Enda O'DowdThe €165bn   plan was agreed amid pressure on Minister for Public Expenditure Michael Mr McGrath from Fianna Fáil backbenchers over spending on regional roads projects. Photograph: Getty ImagesTense negotiations over the level of investment in roads projects saw talks on the National Development Plan (NDP) go down to the wire, it is understood.Government sources said significant investment in roads had been approved as part of the NDP process, which sources said had now been signed off.The €165 billion plan, to be published on Monday, will include a swathe of heavy-spending schemes which will see more than 50 projects with a price tag of more than €100 million included.Lengthy talks took place on Thursday evening between Minister for Public Expenditure Michael McGrath and Green Party leader Eamon Ryan over the balance between roads investment versus public transport, it is understood, before the deal was signed off.Government sources said extra road projects would be named in the NDP, and agreement had been reached during the week on infrastructure investment in both public transport and roads projects.A number of TDs and Senators made their positions clear on roads and other infrastructural investments they feel are vital – and expect Mr McGrath to deliver on next week.Clare TD Cathal Crowe, who raised the issue at the party’s parliamentary party meeting on Wednesday, said the second phase of the northern distributor road between Clare and Limerick must be funded – even in the face of Green Party concerns about building infrastructure for fossil-fuel burning vehicles.“We shouldn’t have a Green Party ideology preventing this from seeing the light of day,” he said.Mr Crowe said he told Mr McGrath “this road is positive and its non-progression leaves the region in limbo”.Mayo TD Dara Calleary, who has asked that the Western Rail Corridor as well as the second phase of the N26 and investment in broadband be included, said that investment in regional infrastructure was needed to help the regions capitalise on remote working trends. “We have to be sensible, realistic and fair, and we still do not have a proper road network in many parts of the regions, especially below national road level.”Only show in townSenator Lisa Chambers, who is also arguing for investment in the Western Rail Corridor, said investment in roads should go ahead, with technologies decarbonising the vehicles on them.“Roads are the only show in town for this particular part of the country. I think it’s premature to say we’re going to stop building roads. If the mode of transport is clean, roads aren’t the problem. The Greens’ roads argument needs to be reconsidered in the light of infrastructure deficiencies in the rest of Ireland.”Tipperary TD Jackie Cahill said it was vital that Fianna Fáil be seen to deliver projects. “It’s critical we’re seen to justify our reason for going into government and that’s to deliver for our constituencies.”

title: philippines president duterte announces retirement from politics
story: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte says he is backing out of an announced plan to run for vice president in next year’s elections and will retire from politics after his term ends. Photograph: Lisa Marie DavidAPPhilippine President Rodrigo Duterte has announced he is retiring from politics and dropping plans to run for vice president in next year’s elections when his term ends, avoiding a legal battle with opponents who questioned the move.He told reporters many Filipinos have expressed their opposition to his vice-presidential bid in surveys and public forums.“The overwhelming sentiment of the Filipino is that I’m not qualified, and it would be a violation of the constitution,” Mr Duterte said.“In obedience to the will of the people... I will follow what you wish and today I announce my retirement from politics.”The 76-year-old, known for his deadly anti-drugs crackdown, brash rhetoric and unorthodox political style, earlier accepted the ruling party’s nomination for him to seek the vice presidency in the May 9th elections.The decision outraged many of his opponents, who have described him as a human rights calamity in an Asian bastion of democracy.Mr Duterte announced his surprise withdrawal from the election after accompanying his former long-time aide, senator Bong Go, to register his own vice presidential candidacy with the ruling party at a Commission on Elections centre.Philippine presidents are limited by the constitution to a single six-year term and opponents had said they would question the legality of Mr Duterte’s vice presidential run before the Supreme Court if he pursued his bid.While two recent presidents ran for lower elected positions after their terms ended, Mr Duterte was the first to consider running for the vice presidency.If he had pursued the candidacy and won, that could have elevated him back to the presidency if the elected leader died or was incapacitated for any reason.Mr Duterte’s withdrawal could also pave the way for a possible presidential run by his daughter.Sara Duterte, mayor of Davao city, has been encouraged by many supporters to make a bid to succeed her father. She has topped independent public opinion surveys on who should lead the country next.But after her father declared he would seek the vice presidency, she announced she would not run for president, saying she and her father had agreed that only one Duterte would run for a national office next year.There was no immediate reaction on Saturday from Ms Duterte, who has gone on a week-long medical leave.Drugs crackdownMr Duterte took office in 2016 and immediately launched a crackdown on illegal drugs that has left more than 6,000 mostly petty suspects dead and alarmed Western governments and human rights groups.The International Criminal Court has launched an investigation into the killings but he has vowed not to co-operate with the inquiry and allow investigators to enter the country.Mr Duterte was a former long-time Davao city mayor, government prosecutor and legislator in a colourful political career that ned more than two decades.He will be remembered by many for his extra-tough approach to criminality that earned him nicknames such as “Duterte Harry”, after Clint Eastwood’s police character who had little regard for the law.When he exits from politics, he is likely to be hounded by lawsuits arising from his violent anti-criminality campaign. He cited that concern in July as one of the reasons why he accepted the ruling PDP-Laban party’s nomination for him to be its vice-presidential candidate.A top human rights group said Mr Duterte will do everything in his power to support a friendly successor and will use his lingering influence in retirement to shield himself from an array of potential criminal charges.Carlos Conde of Human Rights Watch said: “Eluding accountability for human rights abuses is Duterte’s primary concern as his presidency winds down.”–PAStay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: case against cressida dick devastating
story: The case for Dame Cressida Dick’s resignation was already open and shut. We really didn’t need another example of the politan Police Commissioner presiding over a culture of incompetence and cover up to know that she was in over her head, but still she provided it this week with her characteristic recalcitrance over Sarah Everard’s murder. On she ploughs, seemingly oblivious to suggestions that after arguably the most disastrous tenure Scotland Yard has ever witnessed, she should probably call it a day.Yet in refusing to step down over her force’s criminally inadequate vetting of Wayne Couzens, nicknamed “the rapist” by his police officer colleagues, Dame Cressida has not only failed his poor victim and her grieving family – but women everywhere. It pains me to say it because the significant moment in the Met’s 188-year history when Dame Cressida became its first female commissioner should have been cause for continued celebration by the sisterhood.Yet four years on from her appointment, we now find ourselves in the position of having to fight for the right to feel safe on the streets of Britain – with the woman at the helm seemingly refusing to take her fair share of the blame. So much for “leaning in”. Following revelations that Couzens sent grotesquely sexist, racist and homophobic WhatsApp messages to colleagues – and with female officers saying they were too afraid to report male officers for misconduct – we can now add “institutionalised misogyny” to the Met’s growing list of failings on Dame Cressida’s watch.The typically cloth-eared nature of her response was plain to see on Thursday, after Couzens was given a whole life tariff for his unfathomably brutal rape and murder of Miss Everard, when she once again pledged to “learn lessons” from the Met’s mistakes.What happened to the lessons that were supposed to have been learned after Dame Cressida led the team that mistakenly shot dead Brazilian Jean Charles de Menezes? Or the lessons that were meant to have been learned two years ago, following the bloodiest year for homicides in London in a decade?What happened to the lessons that were supposed to be learned over Operation Midland, the Met’s bungled investigation into false allegations of historic child abuse made by the fantasist Carl Beech?Or the lessons that were meant to have been learned after the Independent Panel investigating the murder of private investigator Daniel Morgan found Dame Cressida had obstructed their inquiry into police corruption? The Oxford-educated police chief even managed to bungle the policing of Miss Everard’s vigil, while officers have rightly stood accused of pandering to the Extinction Rebellion and, more recently, Insulate Britain eco-mob.If there is any lesson to be learned here, it is that Dame Cressida has never been fit for the top job – and yet, incredibly, her contract was extended for two years in September, proving once again that failure is the best route to reward in public office.Outside the Old Bailey, again with trademark understatement, Dame Cressida declared: “I recognise that in some people a precious bond of trust has been damaged.” Sorry, “some” people? While I think the public is wise enough to appreciate that the police have a very difficult job to do, in this case they simply didn’t do it well enough. It wasn’t only Couzens who “brought shame on the Met”, as Dame Cressida put it – seemingly determined to make this about just one man. The Met has also brought shame on itself.It was an open secret that Couzens was a drug user with a taste for extreme pornography. And yet no one thought to question why he was still in possession of the warrant card he used to coax Miss Everard into his unmarked car on March 3.If it wasn’t bad enough that Couzens passed the Met vetting programme despite being investigated for indecent exposure by Kent Police in 2015, we now learn that just 72 hours before his attack on Miss Everard, he was reported for indecent exposure at a McDonald’s drive-through restaurant. Staff reported the incident to police, who identified his car from CCTV footage, but he was not arrested, leaving him free to kidnap, rape and murder.Let us be in no doubt of the facts here, amid a flurry of buck passing about “bad apples”. The police knew Couzens was rotten to his core. They had plenty of chances to stop him. Yet thanks to failures in vetting, whistle-blowing and straightforward policing, Miss Everard was killed in the most appalling way imaginable.While I appreciate that there is only one murderer here, someone has to take responsibility for the catastrophic errors that led to Couzens being able to abuse his position of authority with such utterly devastating consequences. Yet instead of assuming liability, as she should, Dame Cressida and her force are once again trying to shift the policing burden onto the public. In the vein of telling victims of theft to track down their own stolen cars, we are now being told that if we do find ourselves “in an interaction with a sole police officer”, we should “seek further reassurance of that officer’s identity and intentions.”As well as asking for “independent verification” such as hearing the voice of an operator on a radio, the latest guidance from the Met is that people who get stopped should ask “where are your colleagues, where have you come from, why are you here and exactly why are you stopping or talking to me?”I’m not sure that’s quite what London Mayor Sadiq Khan meant when he said “serious questions needed to be answered”. Surely the only question the public really needs an answer to is: are there any more rapists and murderers in the police? Funnily enough, women placed under arrest would rather be able to trust the officer in charge, than have to feel the need to “wave down a bus”, “run into a house” or “shout out to a passer-by” to check that he isn’t actually a psychopath. Moreover, rather than publishing yet another “strategy for tackling violence against women and girls”, mightn’t it be an idea for the Met to get its own house in order?Such was the culture of silence around Couzens’s vile behaviour that despite giving female officers “the creeps”, none of the women made a formal complaint against him because of the male-dominated nature of the force. In general, female officers said they were afraid to report their male colleagues for misconduct due to fears they would be abandoned on calls or have their “heads kicked in”. Meanwhile, nothing was made of the fact that Couzens – then a serving officer with the Civil Nuclear Constabulary, having transferred from Kent Police – had repeatedly exposed himself while driving. Even when he was spotted driving to Dover naked from the waist down in 2015, for reasons that remain unclear, the CNC was not informed while Kent Police marked the investigation as “no further action”. And people wonder why the victims of sexual crimes don’t think they are going to be taken seriously by the police? In this case, the police didn’t even take seriously the nefarious behaviour of one of their own.Dame Cressida has rightly said that the Met is “full of people who are good, who work all their lives to protect others”. I know the vast majority of decent, committed police officers are as appalled by what Couzens has done as the rest of us. They deserve better – and so does the public.When the trust has gone, the leadership must go with it.More from NewsApple&#39s encrypted browsing will make it harder for police to investigate dangerous criminalsRoyal Navy recruitment drive in 1960s targeted &#39public and grammar school sixth-formers&#39Queen recalls &#39happy memories&#39 with Prince Philip in Scotland in first remarks since his deathSplit in major cocaine trafficking ring triggers string of beheadingsDrivers risk being &#39fleeced&#39 by 5p per litre petrol price increase amid fuel crisisBicycle theft soared in one of London&#39s experimental green road zonesMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: voters can smell starmers insincerity james bond mile
story: Asked by a reporter who his favourite James Bond was, Labour leader Keir Starmer refused to answer. “I don't have a favourite Bond, but I do think it's time for a female Bond.”This is not a column about the fashionable idiocy of demanding that female actors be cast in established male roles in order that, in some mysterious and unspecified way, sex equality is more quickly achieved. Rather, it is a lesson in that most valuable and rarest of political qualities: authenticity.Most people in this country have a favourite Bond. It is reasonable to expect our politicians to have an opinion on the matter just it would be reasonable to ask them about their favourite football team (a topic on which Starmer himself is far more forthcoming). Since football is at least as trivial a topic as that of James Bond, is it really credible to believe that this man of the people doesn’t have a view as to whether Roger Moore was a better choice to play 007 than Timothy Dalton or Sean Connery?Even that doesn’t matter. Starmer may well be one of the dozen or so people in the country who’s never seen a Bond film and genuinely has no opinion on it. Fair enough. Weird, but fair enough. So why would someone with so little interest in a movie franchise feel so strongly about the need to change the main, iconic character’s sex? Either you don’t care about the character or you care so much about it that you want to demolish nearly 60 years of established character building. Starmer, perhaps unsurprisingly for a modern politician, wants it both ways. This is unwise.When John Smith was leader of the Labour Party, he (perhaps ill advisedly) agreed to appear on BBC Radio 1 to be interviewed, during which event he was asked – and failed to answer – a question about who was at number 1 that week. No one cared because no one thought it was particularly important that a future prime minister (as he was generally considered to be at the time) kept up to speed with the music played by popular beat combos on the wireless and their success in the Hit Parade.But Starmer cannot now claim to have weightier subjects on his mind than the best actor to have played Bond because he followed up his first answer (“I don’t have a favourite”) with a plea for someone of unspecified name but specific sex to play the role in future.This clumsy, cynical attempt to virtue signal what for most people would be an interesting pub conversation (and let it now be observed that Keir Starmer is incapable of carrying on a light-hearted conversation over a pint) is perhaps more relevant than you might at first think. Did Starmer expect the question? I suspect not, given how rubbish his answer was. If it was prepared in advance, that would be even worse.Did he and his advisers reckon the question was a trap? If he answered “Sean Connery”, would he then find himself in a Twitter row about the late Scottish actor’s deplorable record of violence against women? Would Sir Roger or Pierce Brosnan be safer responses? Where the hell is that briefing on George Lazenby?The sheer awfulness of his answer, the utter lack of authenticity that led him to turn a jolly, interesting question into a political point with which vanishingly few people would agree, is informative. Worse, it threatens to remind voters of that epitome of the inauthentic politician, Ed Miliband.Remember when Miliband sacked Emily Thornberry from his front bench after she had Tweeted a snobby photo of a house bedecked with England flags and a white van in the driveway? Remember how the then Labour leader responded when asked in a TV interview what he thought when he saw a white van? And remember the extent to which the nation’s toes curled like the wicked witch’s after Dorothy’s house landed on her?“I think, respect,” said Ed, to the muffled and perplexed howls of embarrassed laughter of the nation.Respect? Why on earth would you see any particular vehicle on the road and think, “Respect”? It was an answer a million miles away from the reality of every other citizen’s life. I would hazard a guess that the rest of us, when we see a white van, think, “Oh, a white van. I’d better get out of its path before it flattens me.”Voters can tell when a politician is seeking to suck up to them, especially when they try to do so by using blatantly cynical language that’s been shaped by the last focus group results. They can tell when someone says something authentic, and when it falls short of that standard – as both Miliband and Starmer’s comments did – they make their own judgment.Starmer’s answer sounded calculated and insincere. If he was worried that giving any answer would alienate the fans of the other five actors who have played Bond, maybe he needs to get a bit of perspective on the subjects that actually shift people’s votes, because movie casting decisions isn’t one of them.And so what if some people disagreed with him? Here we have a politician who said this week that he prioritises winning a general election over his own party’s unity and yet he’s worried about a backlash from Daniel Craig fans? Really?Keir Starmer needs to start behaving and sounding like one of the ordinary voters whose support he desperately needs. Those voters will be going in their droves to watch “No Time To Die” in the next few weeks. Many – perhaps even most of them – will have a view on who the best Bond was and they won’t worry about who is offended by their opinion because no one will be.And in case you’re wondering, the correct answer would have been Connery.More from NewsApple&#39s encrypted browsing will make it harder for police to investigate dangerous criminalsRoyal Navy recruitment drive in 1960s targeted &#39public and grammar school sixth-formers&#39Queen recalls &#39happy memories&#39 with Prince Philip in Scotland in first remarks since his deathSplit in major cocaine trafficking ring triggers string of beheadingsDrivers risk being &#39fleeced&#39 by 5p per litre petrol price increase amid fuel crisisBicycle theft soared in one of London&#39s experimental green road zonesMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: lefts becoming cult losing followers
story: A timely study has found that on the Left, authoritarianism is as much a problem as on the Right. The researchers themselves were surprised - since the 1950s the far Right were inextricably linked to such phenomena. But something since has changed: the traits the researchers identified on the Left will make you wince in recognition: “social uniformity”, “cognitive rigidity” “moral absolutism”, and “willingness to wield group authority to coerce behaviour”. The Labour conference was evidence of this as much as anything else. Take the personality cult remaining around Corbyn, who somehow still dominates the fringes after his demise à la Lenin (Dianne Abbott said it best earlier this week: “Jeremy is always right”). Or indeed, the repudiation of anyone who doesn’t align with Labour’s enlightened knowledge of what is best for The People: 45 per cent of voters at the last estimate voted for a party that is, according to Angela Rayner “homophobic, racist, misogynistic” (and “vile”, in case you were wondering). Those “never f*** a Tory” insignia the young so proudly bear reek of Lebensborn - procreate only with your own. Most awkwardly, in my early twenties I used to think along these lines: I just assumed that if you voted Tory, you had deep-down dishonourable instincts. It sounds risible but is perhaps unsurprising - I didn’t know anyone right-wing, and everyone I did know suggested the Conservative desire to pull yourself up by your bootstraps was a smokescreen for an aversion to the poor and ethnic minorities (a few friends still seem to think as such). I recently came to the troubling realisation my fundamental thinking was redolent of the cultish interpretation of Hinduism I witnessed during parts of my childhood: The unquestioning comfort in a single source of truth, the judgement on others and their materialistic, earthly pleasures as sinful, dirty - as Rayner said Tories are “scum” (and as Trotsky said: “We can only be right with and by the party”): There is no room for nuance away from the dogma handed from on high. Indeed, it is telling that many women who have experienced real, boot-quaking authoritarianism - are fleeing the Left: Katy Morgan-Davies, famously held captive by her abusive father’s Maoist cult for the first thirty years of her life, has quit the Labour party because: “I hear things that remind me very much of the cult, some of the language, the hating on white people or on men. Ayaan Hirsi Ali, once a member of the Muslim Brotherhood said the censoriousness of the Left reminded her of extreme Islamists: “because if you disagree with them, you’re cancelled, you’re out, you’re punished”.How strange that this belief system which prides itself on standing up for the marginalised is dismissive of women who voice unease, makes Rosie Duffield fear for her life - just like every other misogynistic, authoritarian regime we’ve ever been presented with.It is counterproductive because, in my experience, it’s only by giving your beliefs a shake-out, and seeing what still sticks, that you find out what you truly believe in. So many of the Left are defeating themselves: when questioned they reply with the kind of circular justifications I’ve seen only among the ultra-religious and 1984. So-called “liberals” once understood that flexing, moulding and interrogating the way we do things is what has helped society to stamp out isms from sexism to racism - now many are the same inflexible they accused the Right of being. The adage the Left seeks traitors while the Right seeks converts” has never been truer - who wants to enter the fray, only to be excommunicated at the next purge?Perhaps the most headache-worthy aspect of the study is that it took the authors by surprise - the psychologists themselves admitted there was “scant” evidence for the existence of left-wing authoritarianism. But is this surprising, given the way the likes of Nigel Biggar have left professorships, how scientists clubbed together in Lancet op-eds and the like to silence anyone such as Angus Dagleish, who suggested that Covid-19 might have originated in a lab? Left-wing beliefs are ubiquitous among universities and sociologists the research establishment. And it indicates the exact irony of the situation authoritarianism among much of the Left creates complacency about authoritarianism on the Left: One of the things about echo chambers is you can’t see where the walls end.More from NewsApple&#39s encrypted browsing will make it harder for police to investigate dangerous criminalsRoyal Navy recruitment drive in 1960s targeted &#39public and grammar school sixth-formers&#39Queen recalls &#39happy memories&#39 with Prince Philip in Scotland in first remarks since his deathSplit in major cocaine trafficking ring triggers string of beheadingsDrivers risk being &#39fleeced&#39 by 5p per litre petrol price increase amid fuel crisisBicycle theft soared in one of London&#39s experimental green road zonesMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: prime minister must remember conservative principles
story: Taxes are at their highest level for decades, so Oliver Dowden’s words to this newspaper are welcome: the Tories have always kept taxes low and sought to cut them, he says, and that’s where the Prime Minister and Chancellor’s hearts lie, too.Readers will be wondering: if the present Conservative Government is keen on low taxes, when might we expect them to start coming down? We are picking up the tab for lockdown at some point, there needs to be a strategy for creating more wealth. The Tories have traditionally backed lower taxes for moral reasons but also because they pay for themselves. Businesses and workers are going to need all the help they can get if the country is going to “level up” by generating growth.The Conservative Party conference starts tomorrow and Boris Johnson will hopefully use it as a chance to reconnect with the aspirations of his party’s grass roots. They speak for most of the country. From Tunbridge Wells to Hartlepool, voters seek reassurance that crime is being tackled, the borders brought under control, the woke will have their wings clipped and the direction of economic policy will be towards greater freedom, not state control.There is a misunderstanding among some Tories that holding on to the Red Wall necessitates embracing the nanny state and that the Government’s popularity under lockdown is an endorsement of greater bureaucracy. But the desire to live free of control is timeless and universal – this was what Brexit was really about, pushing back the boundaries of the state.Sir Keir Starmer did an unconvincing impersonation of a Blairite in his conference speech. All we ask of Mr Johnson next week is that he remember the principles on which he won election.     More from NewsApple&#39s encrypted browsing will make it harder for police to investigate dangerous criminalsRoyal Navy recruitment drive in 1960s targeted &#39public and grammar school sixth-formers&#39Queen recalls &#39happy memories&#39 with Prince Philip in Scotland in first remarks since his deathSplit in major cocaine trafficking ring triggers string of beheadingsDrivers risk being &#39fleeced&#39 by 5p per litre petrol price increase amid fuel crisisBicycle theft soared in one of London&#39s experimental green road zonesMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: works like flower bud new covid test could end need self isolate
story: A new Covid-19 test will tell sufferers how infectious they are in an effort to reduce how many Britons have to unnecessarily self-isolate if they test positive for the virus.British start-up Vatic has created new tests which are able to spot the parts of the virus which can contaminate others, and give people a simple “yes” or “no” answer as to whether people are infectious.The scientists behind the tests are hopeful they could be used to release Covid-19 sufferers who won’t be able to pass the virus on from self-isolation.Alex Sheppard, co-founder of Vatic, said: “It’s all about staying open, and we think we’re at the vanguard of new technologies coming to the fore which can help us to stay open.“Previously, it was all about not missing a single case so any false positives were not a problem, but now it’s the opposite. We’re at a point where we have to restore the liberties and freedoms that were lost for almost two years now. This is a more suitable technology for that.”The way the test works is by identifying whether or not the virus is active, in a similar way to how a flower bud can appear opened or closed. If the spike in the virus is active, the bud would be open as it would use this to enter human cells. If it is closed, then this would mean the virus is inactive, and the person would not be infectious.People would need to just swab the test in their mouth, rather than needing to take a sample from their throat or nose, and would receive a result in 15 minutes.Vatic’s tests have, so far, produced no false positives in its clinical trials involving around 1,000 people.The company has this week partnered with Abingdon Health, the London-listed test-maker, which previously built fertility tracking tests and developed Covid antibody tests. Abingdon will be making the tests for Vatic under a deal which initially will see it making as many as two million tests a month, but could increase to 100 million tests every year.The tests are not yet on sale to the public, although Vatic has registered the tests with the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) for professional use. It is attempting to get approval for the tests to be used at home, and is also in talks with the Government over how they could form part of UK testing efforts going into the winter.Sheppard said as the virus mutates and tries to become more infectious, it is becoming easier for the test to be able to tell whether people are infectious or not. He said the tests had been built to be future-proof to mutations.“All of the other antigen tests which are out there, it’s not a question of if but when they’ll stop working. Eventually the tests will need to be redesigned because the virus will have mutated. “Our test will always be able to detect the virus insofar as it will enter human cells through the same mechanism, and that wouldn’t change because if it did, it would be a new virus altogether.”Ministers have said they are keen for Britain to start making its own Covid-19 tests, rather than importing them from China.In February, the Government announced it was striking a deal worth up to £374m with Scottish company Omega to start making lateral flow tests in Britain.However, it has yet to decide which Covid-19 tests it wants to be produced.More from NewsApple&#39s encrypted browsing will make it harder for police to investigate dangerous criminalsRoyal Navy recruitment drive in 1960s targeted &#39public and grammar school sixth-formers&#39Queen recalls &#39happy memories&#39 with Prince Philip in Scotland in first remarks since his deathSplit in major cocaine trafficking ring triggers string of beheadingsDrivers risk being &#39fleeced&#39 by 5p per litre petrol price increase amid fuel crisisBicycle theft soared in one of London&#39s experimental green road zonesMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: army start delivering fuel monday
story: :root Desperate bid to end petrol crisis with Army delivering fuel from MondayMinisters have triggered Operation Escalin, with  military personnel to fill "critical vacancies" and get petrol to the pumpsThe fuel crisis has now been going on for a week, Image: PAByRachel Wearmouth:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsSoldiers will start delivering petrol to forecourts from Monday as ministers scramble to end the fuel crisis gripping Britain. Around  military personnel – including  HGV drivers – will be trained at haulier sites to get more petrol to the pumps as part of the Ministry of Defenceaposs Operation Escalin.Troops have been called on despite Boris Johnson announcing a three-month visa scheme that lets foreign lorry drivers work in the UK in the three months up to Christmas.It comes amid the spectre of empty supermarket shelves, closed garages and fears Christmas will be ruined due to the supply chain emergency. Defence Secretary Ben Wallace, said: “Across the weekend over  military personnel will have been mobilised as part of Operation Escalin. “While the situation is stabilising, our Armed Forces are there to fill in any critical vacancies and help keep the country on the move by supporting the industry to deliver fuel to forecourts.”  Shadow Defence Secretary John Healey, said Labour would backed calling in the military as he blamed the Government for the crisis. We know the Army will step up and deliver when asked, but this is a sticking plaster, he said. We need a proper plan to recruit and train more drivers, including improvements to terms and conditions for those working in the sector. The Mirror also revealed earlier today that thousands of firefighters have been sent letters from the Government urging them to take up HGV driving. The Government already faced fury for sending letters to ambulance paramedics, offering fantastic opportunities, attractive pay rates and flexible hours to help solve the shortages. The visa scheme announced last week by Government allows for , drivers and bends immigration rules in recognition of the extraordinary set of circumstances affecting the stability of the UK supply chain. But ministers have admitted just  HGV drivers will be available immediately, with the following , not backfilling roles until late October – meaning disruption will rumble on for months. Labour Leader Keir Starmer has urged the PM to recall parliament over the crisis, warning scores of key workers were still struggling to get to work. He said: “The Prime Minister should be taking emergency action today but yet again he’s failed to grasp the seriousness of the crisis. If it needs legislation, then let’s recall Parliament to get these emergency measures through urgently. “The Prime Minister promised to save Christmas last year and we all know that went disastrously wrong. Now he’s making the same empty promises again. Boris Johnson was warned about this crisis and he did nothing about it. He had the chance to make a plan but ignored it. The Prime Minister needs to get a grip.” The Petrol Retailers Associationsaid that independent stations, which total % of the network were not receiving enough deliveries of fuel. More than a quarter of the PRAaposs membersapos filling stations were still empty on Friday and less than half had both petrol and diesel in stock, said Executive Director Gordon Balmer.  Whilst the situation is similar to recent days, there are signs that it is improving, but far too slowly, he said. Until independents start getting frequent supplies, we will continue to see long queues at forecourts. Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng insisted that the fuel crisis was subsiding, however. He said: Thanks to the immense efforts of industry over the past week, we are seeing continued signs that the situation at the pumps is slowly improving. UK forecourt stock levels are trending up, deliveries of fuel to forecourts are above normal levels, and fuel demand is stabilising. “It’s important to stress there is no national shortage of fuel in the UK, and people should continue to buy fuel as normal. The sooner weto our normal buying habits, the sooner we canto normal. title: david cameron faces another watchdog
story: :root David Cameron faces another watchdog probe over lobbying registerThe Office of the Registrar of Consultant Lobbyists confirmed it was investigating the Tory former Prime MinisterThe former Tory PM is under investigation by the lobbying watchdog Image: REUTERSByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsDavid Cameron is once again being probed by the lobbying watchdog over whether he should have registered as a consultant lobbyist, it was reported last night The Office of the Registrar of Consultant Lobbyists confirmed it was investigating the Tory former Prime Minister, according to the Financial Times. The regulator said it was “in relation to potential unregistered consultant lobbying”, and the paper said an inquiry began around August .It comes after claims earlier earlier this year that the ex-Conseravtive leader, who quit Downing Street in July  following the Brexit referendum, lobbied the then Vaccines Minister Nadhim Zahawi and the then Health Secretary, Matt Hancock, on behalf of US biotech firm Illumina.Mr Cameron has worked as a paid adviser for Illumnia since . Open Democracy reported in July that the ex-PM met Mr Zahawi less than two months before Illumina won £, of contracts over genome sequencing from Public Health England.  In August, the Times reported that in April  Mr Cameron lobbied Mr Hancock regarding a multimillion pound contract with a company owned by the Department of Health. Under rules drawn-up in , when Mr Cameron was in No, people and organisations that lobby ministers or permanent secretaries on behalf of clients are required to register with the regulator. It comes after Mr Cameron was blasted earlier this year over his lobbying of Treasury ministers and officials on behalf of supply chain finance firm Greensill Capital, for which he worked. In the aftermath of the scandal, he said: “As a former Prime Minister, I accept that communications with government need to be done through only the most formal of channels.”  A Department of Health spokesman told the FT the  contract was a follow-on deal to an  sequencing contract with Illumina. “[It] was awarded in the correct way, through the proper process and any suggestion of undue ministerial involvement in the decision making is completely wrong,” the ministry added. A Government spokeswoman told the Mirror: “This contract, signed to help save lives through better diagnosis, was awarded in the correct way, through the proper process and any suggestion of undue ministerial involvement in the decision making is completely wrong. She added: “Extensive due diligence was carried out and as set out in the transparency notice the contact was directly awarded because Illumina was the only company considered to have the technical capability to deliver this crucial work. “The  contract was a follow-on contract to the original sequencing contract with Illumina in  and the company’s expertise is being used to help the government rollout the world’s first whole genome sequencing programme to better diagnose patients with rare disease and certain cancers.” Comment MORE ON The TreasuryConservative PartyFinancial Times Inc.Department of HealthDavid CameronNadhim ZahawiFighting TalkReferendumPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: weve afghanistans first youtuber couple
story: :root Exclusive: Were Afghanistan’s first YouTuber couple - but we could be killed over our videosQudratullah Rajavi and Rana Yazdanpanah use their popular YouTube Channel to post videos of their everyday lives, including clips of them going for hikes, baking bread, playing pranks - but when the Taliban took over they knew their content put their lives at riskQudratullah Rajavi and Rana Yazdanpanah Image: Qudratullah RajaviByDan Hall:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsAs armed Taliban fighters celebrated their shocking capture of Kabul, Afghanistan’s first YouTuber couple knew their lives were in dreadful danger. Qudratullah Rajavi, , and we Rana Yazdanpanah, , had been making videos showing their le as a modern, liberal couple in Afghanistan for years before the terror group took over. Along with their daughter Katayoun, who is just under six months old, the couple were forced to flee for their lives. Qudrat was born in Iran as a refugee of the Afghan civil war in the s, with his family moving back to Afghanistan when he was a teenager. He found work as a translator with Afghan and international NGOs as well as freelance filmmaking work.  Rana had also been a refugee in Iran before coming to Afghanistan at around . She’d recently been working as an administration manager with the presidential office, but had also done modelling and acting work. As recently as last year, Rana had made national news for unashamedly cycling despite constant threats and harassment that female cyclists face. Qudrat says: “We rode bikes together in the streets of Kabul in an attempt to promote respect for women. It’s not common at all for women to bike in Afghanistan.” But it was their YouTube channel, setup in , that would create the most danger when Kabul fell in August. The couple’s sweet videos could have been made by any young couple in Britain – hiking together, baking bread, playing pranks. Qudrat says: “We wanted to show the world that a couple in Afghanistan can also live a happy le like many other couples around the world. “When we saw some popular YouTube couples, we were inspired by their actions and thought we could also do this and show another aspect of Afghanistan. “We showed that people here are also human beings and they have a normal le.” While their videos racked up thousands of views and lots of encouraging comments, not everyone supported what they were doing. Some Afghans from particularly conservative provinces especially objected to Rana’s involvement. Qudrat explains: “It’s not culturally appropriate for women to show themselves in videos and smile and laugh doing fun stuff. “To them, it was somehow weird and abnormal.” Qudrat says the majority of feedback they received on their first video were disapproving. Some took their disapproval even further than comments. “A fake Facebook page was created in our name publishing inappropriate stuff with swearing and offensive words,” Qudrat says.“It humiliated us and said very bad things in an attempt to discourage us from continuing what we do. “It bothered us a lot – but we didn’t give up.” The risk they were taking with their channel was clear even in the content of their videos. In one vlog last summer, in which they take a road trip from Kabul to Daykundi, Qudrat’s cheerily delivered voiceover says: “We are getting closer and closer to Jalrez district, an unsafe area in which Taliban have their own checkpoints – we will not film this area so we can survive.” That video ends teasing a future video which would be a lighthearted look at what traditional village le is like in Afghanistan. But that upload never arrived – instead, after a year of no new content, the first new footage on the channel came in August of this year. It shows Rana alone, in tears, in a clip titled: “My heart aches on the last day before the fall of Kabul”.  Qudrat says: “Rana, in that video, she cries and is frightened because that night, the Taliban captured Kabul. “We were in our homes and didn’t go anywhere because of the danger. “She said: ‘I want to share my feelings in a YouTube video.’” But it was these appearances in publicly available media that put them both at risk. Within days of the fall of Kabul, Qudrat and Rana realised they had to flee. “Sooner or later, the Taliban would start their revenge,” Qudrat says. Reports soon began of Taliban fighters going door to door and executing people they considered enemies. As Hazaras – an ethnic group persecuted by the Taliban – who had publicly lived at odds with the terror group’s warped morality, Qudrat and Rana were in grave danger. “We heard from our relatives that some Taliban members came to our neighbourhoods asking for people who have worked in the military, in the government,” Qudrat says. “Fortunately, the neighbours didn’t know about us – and also we were not there, and that helped us to be safe.” Deciding to leave was necessary for their safety, but it was a heartbreaking decision to take.  Qudrat says: “We lived a happy le and we wanted to stay in Afghanistan. “We were hopeful that we could make progress there because it was our own country, and we were our own boss. “But after the Taliban’s capture of major provinces and Kabul, my we and I saw no future for ourselves or Afghanistan.” Deciding to leave was one thing, but actually getting out was another altogether. Qudrat worked day and night filling in forms and emailing dferent authorities in a bid to get onto an evacuation list. Within days of  August, when US troops were withdrawn from the country, Qudrat, Rana and their baby managed to get onto a list. But the airport was in chaos when they arrived and they couldn’t get in. The family decided to go home – about  minutes before an IS-K suicide bomber detonated a bomb killing at least  people.  Qudrat says: “We were at the Abbey Gate where the suicide attack happened. “We showed our documents to the soldiers but they didn’t pay attention – they only allowed foreign passport holders in. “The explosion was exactly at the sewer where we stood.” They decided it was too dangerous toto the airport after the massacre, and the evacuation deadline passed. They’d lost all hope – when a few days later, they were instructed to travel to another province where there was hope they could be put on a flight after the deadline. Brit journalist Nadene Ghouri, who has been working with an international coalition of volunteers to help at-risk Afghans get to safety, saw the YouTube couple publicly calling for help, and decided she needed to support them. “Rana and Qudrat were the young modern generation of Afghanistan,” Nadene says. “All they were trying to do was show the world the nice side of their country. “Itaposs hard to believe that something as normal as a man kissing his we publicly or baking bread in the pandemic with her is seen as shameful or punishable by the Taliban. “But itaposs the Taliban not Rana and Qudrat who need to be ashamed.” Qudrat and Rana had to move constantly out of safety concerns for nearly three weeks. Sometimes they even had to sleep outside while waiting for news that they would actually be evacuated. Qudrat says: “It was cold and windy at night and everyone got sick, and our baby also got sick and cold. “It was very dficult.” When the news finally came that they would be on a flight, the family were so desperate not to miss their chance that they slept outside by the buses that would take them to the airport in the morning. The night air was still, which allowed mosquitoes to bother the children as they slept. Qudrat says: “The children were all bitten by mosquitoes, their faces were red. “There were lots of rashes.” In the morning they were flown to Qatar and taken to As Sayliyah, a former US Army Base, where the family remain as refugees. Thankfully baby Katayoun is doing well and “smiles a lot”, with the family being comfortable. Although they’re now safe themselves, Qudrat and Rana are still fearful for their loved ones still in Afghanistan. Some have studied or worked in places that put them at risk of reprisal from the Taliban. But Qudrat also fears about them being caught up in a brewing “humanitarian crisis” engulfing the country. “People are unemployed and banks don’t have money,” he says. A tragedy is going to happen there.” For now, Qudrat and Rana face an uncertain future of their own, but they are hopeful they will be moved to the US to begin a new le there. They’d ideally like to go to Los Angeles. Qudrat says: “I want to start a career there in multimedia productions,it’s possible.“Rana wants to become an actress – she wants to be featured in movies with Angelina Jolie because she loves her a lot, especially in Maleficent.”Although they had to close their YouTube channel down when they were hiding from the Taliban, it’s now back online. And they hope to continue making videos when they can.“I have heard that le in the US is pretty dficult,” Qudrat says.“You have to be tough, you have to work hard, becauseyou don’t work hard you’re going to be hungry or homeless.“So we will do our jobs there, but in our leisure time and at the weekends we will for sure produce videos on YouTube.”Do you have a story to share  Email webfeatures@trinitymirror.Comment MORE ON YouTubeTalibanSoldiersCivil warIran" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: dads severe headache during meeting
story: :root Dads severe headache during meeting was sign of killer brain tumourPaul Ashmore, from Liverpool, was suffering from Central Nervous System lymphoma, a rare type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma at the time of his deathJustine said she “never dreamed” Paul wouldn’t make it through Image: UGCByLee Grimsditch:,  Oct | commentsAn excruciating headache that forced a dad-of-two out of a work meeting ended up being a sign of the brain tumour that would lead to his death. Paul Ashmore, a Liverpool local, died on September  after suffering from complications relating to his cancer treatment. The -year-old was suffering from Central Nervous System lymphoma, a rare type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma at the time of his death. He had a long medical history and had previously been diagnosed with Hodgkin’s lymphoma but later went into remission.Justine told theLiverpool Echothat the pair had been together for  years, having met when she had just started university.He was the le and soul of the party. As soon as he walked into the room you knew he was there,” she said. I remember when I first met him I was like aposwho is this guy apos - he was just so bubbly and chatty. He was so warm and friendly with everyone he met. Everyone said he was the nicest guy who always wanted to do the best for people. He was literally my soulmate and I canapost believe heaposs gone. In early , Paul had been diagnosed with Hodgkin lymphoma but after a course of chemotherapy was back to full health. Justine, who found out she was pregnant with her second daughter Naomi during the start of the pandemic last year, said in some way the last -months turned out to be a blessing. She said: We had a lovely year really as we were both working from home. We got to spend quality time together and Claudia was at home. Lockdown had its blessings because we just got to spend so much time together as a family and Iaposll always cherish that. A headache that was so bad it forced him out of a meeting at work in July, this year, turned out to be a brain tumour, with Paul being diagnosed with cancer for the second time in his le. In August, Paul started an intensive course of chemotherapy to treat his central nervous system lymphoma. Justine said the diagnosis was “devastating”. “But again, because he had been through so much we thought okay, this is terrible but thereaposs a treatment plan and weaposll get through this,” she said.  It had gone well but then he developed neutropenic sepsis, which is one of the complications of the treatment as it was such an extreme chemotherapy.Paul was rushed to hospital on September  and died on Sunday, September . A fundraising page has been set up by friends in memory of Paul to help his family at this devastating time. Speaking of his passing, Justine said she “never dreamed” he wouldn’t make it through. “I think also he used to hide how bad he was feeling, he was always so brave and strong. We didnapost think anything would ever get him,” she said. I donapost feel like Iaposve fully processed it yet. I canapost really cope with whataposs happened. Iaposve got so much support around me - my family and friends have been amazing. Claudia is very upset but she seems to be coping well. She talks about him all the time. When she finds a feather on the floor she says, aposThataposs from Daddyapos. Her youngest, Naomi, also recognised her ‘da da’ when the family were looking at photos, Justine said. “I donapost want her to forget him,” she said. He was to me the greatest husband I could have wished for.
