title: thought for the week september 24 2021
story: Isn#t it amazing how a new-born infant can grab hold of your heart  I was filled with so much love and pride and I prayed that his le would be blessed.It so happened that the Gospel reading set for the Sunday after I met my grandson was, in part at least, about a little child.​Mark tells us Jesus was walking ahead of his disciples on the way to Capernaum. When they got there Jesus asked them: #What were you arguing about along the way #They couldn#t answer, for they had been arguing about which of them was the greatest. They were silent, because they#d been caught out.Then Jesus took a little child in his arms and said to them: #Whoever welcomes one such child in my name welcomes me, and whoever welcomes me, welcomes not me but the one who sent me.#Greatness, Jesus was saying to them, is found in welcoming and receiving into our arms someone vulnerable, powerless and dependent, regardless of age.Greatness is found not in what we have accomplished but in what we have done and given to #the least of these#, the hungry, thirsty, naked, sick, and imprisoned: the symbolic children in each of our lives.Greatness never makes itself superior over another. It is not about me, my job, my reputation, my status. Our greatness is revealed in our service and care of others.Max is doing well, by the way, and I can hardly wait to see him again.God bless you and yours, from biggest to littlest, today and always.

title: gardening tips for adding autumn colour
story: Many flowers are still blooming and the leaves on trees and shrubs are beginning to change to fiery colours like red, yellow and orange.It#s a good time to plant trees, shrubs and perennials as the soil still has some warmth and will help to get them established. Try and get evergreens planted by the end of the month.Dormant roses are now available at local nurseries and garden centres and are very good value for money.You can easily create a rose garden for the coming year that will provide beautul flowers and fragrance from early summer through to autumn.Before planting, mix in some good quality compost and make sure the plants are watered well once planted.It#s an excellent time to plant coners as well. Coners are cone-bearing seed plants and include cedars, cypresses, firs, junipers, larches, pines, spruces and yews.While being practical and useful, coners are also visually stunning and can transform a garden into something quite magnicent.They are a wonderful way of adding colour and shape to your outdoor space, particularly as many coners change colour throughout the year.With several hundred ieties available in the UK, there is one to suit every type of garden, and they are easy to look after.They need good drainage and water to get them established, but once growing will need little attention as they are pretty disease resistant and maintenance free.In addition to coners, another way to bring colour to the garden at this time of year is with autumn bedding plants.One of the most exciting group of plants to brighten up any part of the garden is heuchera.Native to North America, heucheras were originally grown for their flowers – dainty spikes of red, pink and white bells.They carry their plume like flowers high above their crowns of leaves, but gardeners are now mainly interested in their foliage which comes in a iety of colours.Heucheras grow in full or partial sun, in well composted soil and are fairly pest resistant.They can be established as ground cover in many garden situations like under trees where grass could struggle.October is often a time spent clearing up after the summer and preparing for the winter and spring ahead so here are some top tips for jobs next month from the Royal Horticultural Society:

title: blue bin recycling service to start in kintyre and gigha
story: It comes after a controversial decision by Argyll and Bute councillors in February not to extend Kintyre Recycling Limited#skerbside collection contract which it had fulfilled since .The council says the new service is designed to make it more convenient for people in Kintyre to recycle and will be sustainable in the long-term as new government legislation for waste disposal and recycling comes into place.The new dates for scheduled uplts are on the council website at www.argyll-bute.gov.uk kintyre-new-recycling-serviceThey can also be downloaded and printed out as calendars.Those who previously received a printed copy of the calendar will be sent a new one, and those who receive an assisted uplt for their green household waste bin, will automatically receive an assisted uplt for their new blue bin.The materials picked up for recycling in Kintyre go to the Lingerton waste and recycling facility, in Lochgilphead, which is operated by Renewi on behalf of the council.Once there, it is bulked up with the rest of the blue bin recycling from Mid Argyll and sent on to a materials recycling facility in Linwood.Information on how the dferent types of material are sorted and processed can be found on the council#s website at www.argyll-bute.gov.uk what-happens-your-recyclingA very small percentage of properties, mainly tenements, will stay on a bagged service. Residents in these properties should now have received a letter.Bags will be delivered to properties quarterly those who run out can collect more from the Burnet Building or Aqualibrium or by calling  .#If you haven#t received your blue bin please call us on   and we#ll arrange to have one delivered to you,# said a council spokesperson.

title: connor is tarberts junior champion
story: The threat of wet and windy weather did not daunt the enthusiasm of the young golfers, who took part in three dferent competitions.The junior champion was Connor MacRae, group three champion was Aiden Kerr, group two champion was Jack Sinclair and group one champion was Macey Fair.As part of their prizes, the children received a British Open top from Portrush which was kindly signed by European Tour star Robert MacIntyre.#Congratulations to everyone who participated and many thanks to Lesley at Loch Fyne Gallery for her sponsorship,# said a club spokesperson.#Thanks to Captain Kenny for organising the coaching and the championship. See you all next season.#At Glenralloch last Saturday, the gents competed for the September Medal in poor overhead conditions although the course was in terric condition with the greens running the best all year.The only disappointment apart from the weather was the poor turnout.Despite a horror start with a seven, John MacNab recovered well to take first place with a - for a nett , with Andrew Henderson on  and Jamie Stuart on .Bruce MacNab took first scratch on  including two precious magic twos.The next trophy for the gents is the Glenralloch Cup next Saturday, October .

title: council to host education climate summit
story: The event will take place via an online  on Wednesday October  and Thursday October  – a week before the United Nations Climate Change conference COP in Glasgow – and will see a range key speakers joining forces to raise awareness about a iety of climate change issues.Each session will last about one hour and will include presentations by a wide selection of groups, including The Scottish Association for Marine Science, schools, ALIEnergy, Wreckspeditions Dive Charters Ltd, Time for Change Argyll, and the Hebridean Whale and Dolphin Trust.#Argyll and Bute Council has signed up to meet Scotland#s target of achieving #net zero# by ,# said Councillor Yvonne McNeilly, policy lead for education.#We have one of the lowest carbon footprints anywhere in the UK and I firmly believe thatwe all make some changes, even small ones, we could become the first local authority to achieve #net zero# per head of population.#Education is at the very heart of thiswe are to succeed and our schools are already doing amazing things to help raise awareness of global issues in our fight against climate change.#This summit will be a great opportunity for our communities to come together and showcase what they are doing to make a dference.#It will enable us to unite and highlight the challenges we are facing and what we can all do to help overcome them.#The key speakers taking part in the summit have each geared their presentations towards a specic audience, from school pupils to local businesses, so there really is something to interest everyone.#I would encourage everyone to sign up to at least one of the sessions and help us to build a brighter, greener future for all.#To see the full programme of events and sign up, visit https:bit.ly Educationclimatesummit

title: sea is the gateway for getting gravel to gigha
story: A shipment of type-one gravel sailed from Glensanda Quarry on the south coast of the Morvern peninsula.#We needed a vast amount of material for our Gateway to Gigha project which will upgrade and create new pathways totalling a distance of more than nine kilometres,# said Jane Millar, Isle of Gigha Heritage Trust development manager.#Fortunately, a plan was pulled together to have the aggregate shipped in, rather than brought via lorries which would cause issues with road-use, ferry capacity, and the project#s carbon footprint.#Path building will take place this autumn, with the hope that people will be able to start using some routes in early spring . This will mean our residents and visitors can explore Gigha at ease.#The Gateway to Gigha project is supported by the Low Carbon Travel and Transport Challenge Fund and the National Lottery Heritage Fund.It is hoped it will encourage and promote the sustainable use and protection of Gigha#s landscape and assets.As well as the construction and upgrading of paths across the island, new bikes and e-bikes will be available to hire next to the ferry slip to reduce the need for cars.The IGHT hopes that by improving the island#s foot and cycle path network and providing more information, as well as reducing the number of car-borne visitors to Gigha, visitors and residents will learn more about its environment, landscape and assets and how best to protect them.

title: district news october 1 2021
story: There was a heroes# welcome for the Over the Hill hikers as they ed to Tarbert after conquering Ben Nevis for Parkinson#s UK.Piper John Hunt serenaded Don Murray, Tony Baccoli, Callum MacFarlane, Will Hemphill and Tom Lewis as they ed on September , having raised more than £, for the charity.The team was, of course, given huge support by the people of Tarbert, the Corner House bar and many others.Margaret MacNeill of the Corner House posted on social media: #We are delighted the wonderful Over the Hill team has raised in excess of £, – Gt Aid to be added.#Thank you to the Frigate Hotel, Kilbrannan Bar in Campbeltown and Renewi Lochgilphead for promoting and collecting sponsor money. Thanks also to the Secret Baker and One Fyne Deli for preparing the food. Also to John Hunt for piping. It caused a wee stir on Thursday lunchtime.#Parkinson#s UK is our chosen charity and we are humbled by your generosity. Most of all we have to say a huge thank you to Don, Will, Tony, Tom and Callum for choosing to support Parkinson#s UK.#ISLAY:People of all ages and abilities are being given the unique opportunity to walk or run Islay Airport#s runways in a fun-filled fundraiser for Scotland#s Charity Air Ambulance .Organised by the airport#s firefighting crew from Highlands and Islands Airports Limited , the charity event tomorrowwill see the runways closed and the public take over for their km challenge.Event organiser, firefighter Lorna MacInnes, said that around  people had already signed up for the fundraiser and she expected many more to follow.#People on Islay know the amazing work that SCAA does for the folk on the islands,# she said, #and they#re keen to do their bit and give something back.#The air ambulances are literally a leline for our community and we thought it would be a great idea to combine fundraising for them with a unique event.#The October  event will be the first time people have had access to the island airport#s runways and the firefighting crew is confident the whole island will get behind their efforts.#You don#t have to be super-fit to join in,# stressed Lorna. #This is an event for everyone.#It#s all flat ground and the views are amazing! Evenyou just dawdle your way round and leave the record-setting to the runners, you#ll have a lovely time.#Children can opt to take on a shorter one-mile route and the organisers are hopeful that the island#s schools will join in.#Some of the airport firefighters will be running in full kit and we#re also keen to see other  service colleagues sign-up in support as well as family groups, work colleagues and social groups,# said Lorna.#And the fun will go ahead – no matter the weather.#Eventhey#re not doing the walk run, people will be very welcome to attend and enjoy some refreshments and home baking.#Funds will be raised through an entry fee – £ for adults and £ for children – and a spectacular raffle supported by organisations and businesses on the island.Teas and coffees are being supplied by HIAL.#SCAA#s helicopters, pilots and paramedics are always there for the people of Islay,# concluded Lorna. #This is a chance for the whole community to show that we can be there for them.#Nick Harvey, SCAA#s director of fundraising and communications, praised the firefighters# imagination in creating a unique fundraiser for the charity.#We#re hugely indebted to them for their support and to the people of Islay for getting behind this event,# he said.#SCAA relies entirely on public donations to fund our le-saving service  hours a day,  days a year, and this is exactly the type of fundraising event which helps keep us in the air.#We are proud to be able to serve those most in need in our island communities and to be a regular visitor to Islay when serious illness or injury strikes.#I#m sure the runway run will be an incredibly enjoyable event and good luck – and thank you – to everyone taking part.#Anyone wanting to take part in this unique opportunity is invited to just show up on the day with their entry fee.

title: from our files october 1 2021
story: Negotiations for the purchase of Machrihanish airbase have been #delicate and intricate# but the community buyout group plans to hold a public meeting soon, as the proposals reach a final stage.Ian Wardrop, who chairs the Machrihanish Airbase Community Company , told the Courier this week that things were so advanced that they were advertising for an extra director to join the board.#Discussions over the summer have been delicate and intricate, involving many interested bodies, to try to achieve the best outcome for the community,# said Mr Wardrop.#As soon as final proposals are known we will hold a public meeting for discussion and consideration of all aspects by the wider community to maximise participation.#Campbeltown Grammar School scored a Scottish first this week.It wasn#t in sport or music or exams but in politics.For the first time ever, school students have taken part in a housing consultation for the Scottish Parliament.Sixth formers have been studying, and giving their opinions on, the consultation exercise for the creation of a Scottish Social Housing Charter.Steve Byrne, a member of the Dalintober and Millknowe Tenants and Residents Association, is the vice chairman of the Highlands and Argyll and Bute Regional Network of Registered Tenants Associations.He said he was keen that young people were consulted during the work on the housing charter as they were tomorrow#s householders and their views should be taken into consideration.So Steve went along to the grammar school on Monday and joined sixth form pupils and their teacher Cathy Cameron as part of their careers activities it is something they can add to their CVs.TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGOThe annual Campbeltown old folk#s civic reception dinner is back on again next Monday following a last-minute offer from Kintyre Community Radio and the Bank of Scotland.The dinner was cancelled earlier this month after Argyll and Bute Council was unable to process the funding application in time.Normally the event is financed by the council, but due to a number of administrative changes this year associated with the reorganisation of local government, it was unable to find the money in time.#There was a dficulty in finding the proper home for the application and that led to a delay in it being processed,# said Mr Charles Reppke from corporate services.#In the district council days, it was paid for from a pre-marked ring-fenced area of the budget.#But with the arrival of the new authority, that budget was not transferred as a ring-fenced amount.#The old folk#s civic reception dinner has been an integral part of the old folk#s week since  with the council providing the funds for it every year.This year#s hiccup, however, has left some people quite unimpressed.Councillor George McMillan said: #I think there#s been a bit of a muddle and some mismanagement.#It used to be paid for from the civic reception budget, but on this occasion nobody seems to know who was responsible.#I thought the money was supposed to have been transferred over to the social work department.#FIFTY YEARS AGOWork has now started on Campbeltown Shipyard#s most unusual order to date – a -foot car ferry for Argyll County Council.The vessel, which is to ply between Cuan and Luing, will be capable of carrying  passengers and five cars, or alternatively a cargo of  tons.Portable livestock pens will be provided with the ship, enabling her to carry  cattle.Powered by two Scania Vabis D engines developing  HP each the ferry is to have a beam of  feet.Leading ramps will be situated on the starboard bow and port quarter, cabin seating for  passengers will be located aft.The vessel is expected to be completed in about six months.#Big Jimmy# Reid, chairman of the Upper Clyde Shipbuilders# Joint Shop Stewards Committee, was the guest of Campbeltown Labour Party at a special meeting in the Royal Hotel last Sunday.In his own inimitable style, Jimmy spoke out frankly and forthrightly in criticism of the Conservative government, particularly on the question of unemployment.During a long and lively discussion with local party members, he answered many questions on the Upper Clyde Shipbuilders# crisis.The action taken at UCS was unique and unprecedented, he said, but public support had been overwhelming.#The men are in fine spirit,# he added, #and win or lose we will fight this to the bitter end.#Mr Reid was spending the weekend in Campbeltown taking a #well-earned break# away from it all. He ed to Clydeside on Monday evening.ONE HUNDRED YEARS AGOOn Saturday afternoon amatch between the Tayinloan and Lochend quoiting clubs was played on Lochend quoiting ground.Beautul weather favoured the match, which was witnessed by quite a large crowd. At Tayinloan, the pitch is on a slope in town it is quite level.This was a great disadvantage to the visitors, as they found dficulty in judging distances on the dferent pitch. They also used light quoits, which told against them.However, they played well, and gave the local team a good game.After the game, which ended in a victory for the local club, the visitors were entertained to tea in Mr Quigley#s tea rooms.In the matter of weather, September has behaved very nicely.Harvest festival services will be held in Castlehill Church on Sunday.Summertime ends on Sunday. At night, the clock should be put back an hour.Enrolment for the evening continuation classes in town will be carried out on Friday night.Mr JM Brown is opening a singing class for young men and women in Lochend Church Hall on Friday th October.Local bowlers are bringing the season to an end on Saturday, when the closing games will be played on both Stronvaar and Argyll greens.Campbeltown Parish Council at the meeting on Monday postponed the imposition of the assessments until the valuation role is completed.The local Football Association are inviting entries for the league competition and aspirants for the job of referee are asked to submit their applications.The club for ex-servicemen in Union Street will be formally opened on Friday night at : the ceremony will be performed by Colonel Charles Mactaggart, CST CIE TMS .

title: health centre to host drop in flu clinic
story: The clinic will be held from am to pm at Campbeltown Health Centre – note the change of venue this year.It is strictly for those aged  and over, or under  with a chronic health condition, who are registered with Campbeltown Medical Practice.People with a history of the following conditions are advised to have the flu vaccine: asplenia, asthma, bronchitis, a BMI of  or more, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, chronic heart disease, chronic kidney failure, cystic fibrosis, diabetes, emphysema, HIV infection, liver problems, multiple sclerosis, undergoing chemotherapy.This is a walk-through clinic those attending must wear a face covering and keep a two-metre distance from others.Patients are being asked to note that this is a clinic for the flu vaccine only Covid vaccine boosters will begin at a later date.

title: heritage centre revealed as historic location
story: Well done to the readers who recognised the mystery historic building in last week#s Down Memory Lane as Campbeltown Heritage Centre.We included a small clue when we said it was a building with a lot of history as the Big Kiln Street structure houses an extensive collection of artefacts relating to Kintyre#s heritage from around  to the present day.The social history collection, which includes sections on coal-mining, farming, fishing, the harbour, ship-building, whisky and Campbeltown at war, has been described as one of the finest on the west coast of Scotland.Visitors can also research their own family history using online resources and local records and papers.On occasion, the heritage centre marks special events and anniversaries by putting on specic exhibitions.There is no entrance fee, with the heritage centre being supported by donations and volunteers.The building itself has an interesting past.It was built in  as Lorne Street Church, bringing together the congregations of the former Gaelic Free Church and English Free Church, which had both jointly stood on the site before.Because of the unusual and striking alternating colour scheme of its stonework, which created a striped pattern, the church became known as the #tartan kirk#.The church was closed in , and since  has served as home to Campbeltown Heritage Centre.Currently closed because of the Covid- pandemic, the heritage centre is usually open from April to October each year.Even while it remains closed, there is plenty to see outside. As well as the building#s own unique features, a very rare artefact is on display externally.A minenwerfer, a German mine thrower or mortar, which was presented to the heritage centre in , was conserved and redisplayed outside the building#s main entrance.It is also worth taking a look at the heritage centre#s logo which is displayed on an outer wall.The mermaid which features on it was inspired by one on Campbeltown Cross, a late medieval carved cross which is one of the town#s most iconic monuments.The design on the logo – with long hair and scales – is based on detailed descriptions after reported sightings of a mermaid close to Feochaig, between Campbeltown and Southend.

title: leader october 1 2021
story: Congratulations to The Rotary Club of Campbeltown which is celebrating its th anniversary.The group has struggled with the impact of Covid pandemic restrictions and is in need of new members.Some misconceptions perhaps exist about Rotary clubs in general, including that they are for men or those who are retired.This couldn#t be further from the truth the Campbeltown club#s current president is female and members simply have to be aged  or over.There are many benefits of being part of a Rotary club, including: social networking and meeting people from dferent walks of le  developing personal and vocational skills enhancing understanding of local and global issues making connections that could lead to business opportunities rewards from Rotary#s member benefits programme working with leading national and international charities and being part of a global community.Well done to Springbank Distillery for taking the plunge and making changes to its packaging and production processes to help protect the environment.It must be nerve-wracking to be one of the first –not THE first – to make such progressive changes in such an illustrious industry but agree that whisky fans are bound to care more about what#s inside the bottles than what surrounds them!

title: letters october 1 2021
story: On Monday last week I was walking along Main Street as the high school students were making their way home and a young student pulled out one of the plants from the pot outside Wee Toon Trends and, after knocking the soil off, he threw it at his friends.I told him to pick it up and replant it, which he did.The boy is the exception rather than the norm but his behaviour reflects badly on the whole school and I hope he has learnt his lesson.The shopkeepers are making an effort to brighten up the town#s appearance but incidents like this will discourage them.NFU Scotland is calling on the UK Government to address the nation#s growing labour crisis, which is undermining all parts of the food and drink supply chain, leading to signicant losses on some Scottish farms and resulting in a growing number of empty shop shelves.The #BackBritishFarmingDay on September  came as a UK Government announcement of a free trade #agreement in principle# between the UK and New Zealand is believed to be imminent.Having agreed in June to provide unfettered access in the future to Australia, the cumulative impact of another deal with a major exporting nation has huge signicance for Scottish farmers and crofters.With so much to celebrate about the quality and standards of our food and drink, #BackBritishFarmingDay was a fantastic opportunity to thank the nation for their incredible support throughout Brexit and Covid-.NFU Scotland, both independently and in conjunction with the Scottish food and drink industry, has written several times to UK Government calling for measures that address the shortfall in both seasonal and permanent staff.Should it fail to do so, I have absolutely no doubt that the situation will deteriorate further.It is galling to hear that the UK Government is on the verge of signing up to another free trade deal that will permit a growing level of imports while delivering very little to our food and drink sector in .The blunt fact is that neither deal has been afforded any kind of proper parliamentary scrutiny as the government#s promised Statutory Trade and Agriculture Commission has yet to be established.Safeguards against market disruption are also promised, but the cumulative impact of these deals will be profound for UK farming.If handled badly, these may make it impossible for some of our family farming businesses to continue to compete with high levels of low-cost imports produced to standards that would not be allowed here.

title: pupils knocked out of strathclyde cup
story: Campbeltown Pupils suffered a disappointing home defeat last Saturday at the hands of Govan outfit Harmony Row.A slow start saw the Pupils concede two goals in the opening  minutes, both arising from similar situations where the Pupils were stretched in defence and undone by smart finishes after cutbacks from wide positions.An injury to recently-ed full-back Jamie Burns midway through the first half necessitated a switch from right-back to left-back for Martin McCallum, a good creative outlet for the Pupils on the day.However, McCallum had to be on his guard to help his team at the other end after a Harmony Row striker rounded keeper Craig Lamont, but the striker#s side-footed finish did not have the pace and the recovering McCallum cleared the ball off the line.Michael McKinlay, himself playing through the pain barrier, slotted in at right-back, and the Pupils steadied the ship slightly before the half-time interval arrived.However, there was further bruising for the Pupils on the pitch with only  minutes played, when Harmony Row made it -, after a ball, again from a wide position, was turned home first time into the roof of the net.The match was then put well out of the Pupils# reach after the visitors scored their fourth goal with an hour played.A similar rout to the Pupils# - defeat to the same visiting team on league duty in early September looked to be on the cards.The final  minutes of the match was positive for the McFadyens-sponsored Pupils, thanks in part to the introduction of Conner McMurchy in attack.The young forward asked questions of the Harmony Row central defensive pairing, and when he latched on to a high delivery into the box from a free kick wide on the right, he turned provider for sweeper John McCallum to side-foot firmly home from close range to get the Pupils off the mark.Into the latter stages, the scores could have been higher on both sides, prevented only by good saves from both Lamont in the Pupils goal – who had travelled from his Edinburgh home to play for the team – and the Harmony Row keeper, who showed strong hands to ert a shot from Rhys Casci, the previous weekend#s hat-trick hero against Harthill Royal, wide of his right-hand post.The match sponsor was Wee Toon Trends.Tomorrow , the Feathers Inn-sponsored Pupilsto league action, welcoming old SAFL rivals Finnart, recently moved to the WoSFL from the Caledonian AFL, to Kintyre Park.Kick off is at pm. For more information, find @PupilsAFC on Twitter or Campbeltown Football on Facebook.

title: thought for the week october 1 2021
story: They are responsible for the pollination of about  per cent of trees and bushes on the entire planet. Yet we often treat them in a dismissive way.Let#s think about some insects.Take the bluebottle. How often has it outwitted us with its amazing flight paths, ducking and ing to avoid our threatening gestures.While we have developed some of the most sophisticated flying machines the world has known, none can match the bluebottle in its agility.We have mentioned pollination. What insect is more important than the bee as it goes about its business from flower to flower ensuring that the plants will produce seed for another year and giving us honey as a product of its labours.How beautul too are its colours and the structure of its body – a remarkable little insect.Then there is the humble moth and its gravity-defying antics walking across ceilings. It has a very fragile body but in its short le can nevertheless act out its own acrobatic skill in an amazing performance.Or we may think of the spider and the beauty of its web, perhaps seen on a frosty winter morning. A true work of art woven with such delicacy.In the bible we read this: #Go watch the ants, you lazy person. Watch what they do and be wise. Ants have no commander, no leader or ruler, but they store up food in the summer and gather their supplies at harvest.# From this we can learn four things helpful to living: be diligent and hard-working have an #I can do it# attitude plan ahead remember teamwork is important.

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as ldquoa real dream come true.She said: ldquoWe are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk ndash The Cheese Lady ndash has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: ldquoWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.ldquoWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.ldquoAlso, Irsquom hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: ldquoWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  Thatrsquos fantastic.ldquoAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: ldquoI think we are in a good place.ldquoWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than pound,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: ldquoWe are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.ldquoMary has raised a fantastic pound, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: ldquoThis year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.ldquoIrsquom walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: musselburgh-boxer-delighted-turn-professional
story: Robbie Graham, , who is originally from Craigmillar but now lives in Gorebridge, is working with a promoter and is set to fight under JL Boxing Club, which earlier this year opened a boxing, fitness and martial arts centre at a premises which was formerly the Big Pick  Zero Waste shop on High Street.He said: ldquoMy association with the gym came through my long-term relationship with coach Paul Barbour, who is a coach at JL Boxing Club. He coaches alongside the head coach Jay Tuveri.ldquoBy introducing me to him and the club, Irsquom getting the opportunity to work on my fighting skills, make improvements and to have a full support for my career while joining the team of fighters.Robbiersquos debut as a professional boxer is being discussed and, with the easing of Covid- restrictions, he is shortly hoping to have a date for his first pro welterweight fight.He said: ldquoI feel excited and very humble at the chance to fight at professional level. It feels amazing to finally have all you have worked for come together and to sign a professional contract.ldquoGoing professional for me, itrsquos only the beginning but I also mean business.ldquoIrsquom prepared to work the hardest to move up the ranks and continue to chase my dreams of winning professional titles.ldquoIt also means I can dedicate my hard work and success to all my children, my partner. It shows to the younger generation that anything is possibleyou believe it.

title: womans-raises-hundreds-birthday-donations-charity
story: She asked friends for donations for the charity instead of gts to celebrate her th birthday.ldquoMy wonderful friends came up trumps and raised pound ndash almost double what Irsquod hoped for, she said.Mrs Fairnie, who lives on Promenade, added: ldquoI was an active supporter when I was able and the mission is still close to my heart.ldquoI would like to thank everyone who gave donations.The Fishermenrsquos Mission is the only fishermenrsquos charity that provides emergency support alongside practical, financial, spiritual and emotional care. It helps all fishermen, active or retired, and their families.Mrs Fairnie, whose husband John was a fisherman, has enjoyed a long association with the Fishermenrsquos Mission, serving as an area secretary and volunteering as a collector.The current president of Musselburgh Sea Cadetsrsquo unit management committee, she has raised a total of pound this year for charity.In addition to her birthday gesture for the Fishermenrsquos Mission, earlier this year she joined the sea cadetsrsquo virtual sponsored walk ndash which took them from their base in Musselburgh to the organisationrsquos HQ on Lambeth Road, London, and back home ndash after recovering from heart surgery.She clocked up more than , steps in the garden of her home, completing  steps around her garden daily with the aid of a walking stick. She raised pound for the cadet unit, which was founded by her father-in-law Robert Fairnie MBE BEM, along with Jimmy Brown.

title: discarded-dog-poo-bags-discovered
story: Callum Colquhoun, accompanied by Alister Hadden, chairman of Wallyford Community Council, walked around the east side of the village after a recent community survey identied dog fouling as the biggest complaint.Their route included Salters Road, the lsquoPugrsquo path, the safe school walk route, rear of the industrial estate and through the park, taking in the community centre.Mr Colquhoun, who works for East Lothian Council, said: ldquoWe came across a number of full discarded dog bags and dog faeces that had not been picked up, sadly outside the school gates, the verges on the new road, the industrial estate and play park wooded area.ldquoThe most prolic area was at the substation near to the new primary school, where a large number of full discarded dog bags have been dumped. All the dog bags at this area are likely to come from the same dog owner.ldquoFirstly, it is an offence to allow your dog to defecate and fail to pick up immediately. You must discard the waste in a suitable bin. Failure to do so may result in a fixed penalty of pound.ldquoWhilst the community wardens and some other council staff have the powers to impose this fixed penalty, it is always dficult catching these offenders. It only takes a handful of offenders to cause the problem. Most dog owners are creatures of habit, they walk their dog twice a day, the dog does the toilet twice a day, it gets walked  times in one week. It doesnrsquot take long to mount up.Mr Colquhoun said the assistance of the local community in reporting offenders would ldquogreatly help the council.ldquoWe can give a fixed penalty on a strong statement from a member of the public, he said.ldquoWe just need to know the date and time of the offence, the name of the person, addresspossible, a description of the dog, the location where the offence took place and any other relevant information.ldquoYou all live locally, there will be more chance that you know and see who is committing this unacceptable behaviour. Working together, we can help reduce this problem.Local children and community councillors recently joined forces in a bid to keep safe routes to school in Wallyford free of dog dirt.Youngsters put their artistic talents to good use to design posters which have been put up to reinforce the message for dog owners.They are being urged to use the  litter bins around the village, which are emptied by the councilrsquos amenity services.The initiative was also supported by the council and Wallyford Primary School Parent Council.

title: plans-submitted-turn-dunbar-building-home
story: Previous plans for the property on Belhavenrsquos Brewery Lane to become The Catrsquos Pyjamas were put on ice last year.Now, fresh proposals are being considered by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department to see the existing office turned into a house.The building would feature two upstairs bedrooms under the plans from OSC Ltd.A design and access statement with the latest application notes: ldquoThe re-purposing of this building will ensure the future le of the building make a positive contribution to the need for housing accommodation and will make a positive contribution to the community.An off-street parking space would be provided.

title: grieving-marc-sleeping-tent-leave-home
story: Marc Dale, , told the Courier that he moved into a one-bed council property on Preston Avenue, Prestonpans, with mum Gillian Woods  years ago but alleges he was kicked out of the property with little notice shortly after his motherrsquos death and just days before her funeral.Marc, a former Preston Lodge High School pupil, left education at the age of  to look after his bedbound mum at the Prestonpans property after she suffered a le-changing stroke.Gillian was admitted to East Lothian Community Hospital in November  with bowel cancer.She passed away at the hospital, with her son by her side, on June .Following her death, Marc alleges that he was evicted from the council property because the home was adapted for disabled living ndash his former property is now boarded up and he has been left to camp in the garden of a trusted friend with his faithful six-year-old dog Rocky.He claims that he was sent an eviction notice and ordered to leave his home by July  ndash just two days before he buried his mother on July .Marc was ultimately allowed to stay in the home until August .He says he was advised by housing officers to seek homeless accommodation but he discounted this option as he was told he would not be able to take Rocky with him.Rocky and the tent Marc has been sleeping in Eight months prior to his motherrsquos death, he claims he was told by officials that, because of health conditions, he would be put into temporary housing.Marc believes his only option now is to camp outdoors ndash despite torrential rain, heavy winds and the threat of people turning up at his tent.He said: ldquoPets are family and should be with me no matter what, Irsquoll stay all winter.ldquoI broke my back in seven places on my spine in November and my mum got rushed to hospital and died months later.ldquoThe housing officers approached me eight months before she passed away and promised to have a temporary flat available for me due to my medical conditions, as I suffer from bad seizures which is what broke my back. I have brittle bone disease as well.ldquoA man in my condition could even die in these cold nights and conditions.Marc has since taken to social media to share his story with friends and followers.His Facebook post has been shared more than , times ndash one Facebook user has claimed it has been shared in more than  dog groups worldwide.A number of people have come forward to share words of support with Marc on social media.One commented: ldquoThis is East Lothian Councilrsquos duty of care to provide secure accommodation. Absolute disgusting! What is priority these days  This country is so corrupt it sickens me.Another added: ldquoIf you need anything at all, mate, you or the dog, let people know, therersquos gonna be lots of folk willing to help.Marc and his beloved dog RockyA third said: ldquoTherersquos people offering help and folk offering you places to stay, I donrsquot live near you but I hope you see the messages.A final comment read: ldquoThis is so heartbreaking. He cared for his mother, she passed away, then they evicted this poor man and his pooch and said get rid of the dog.ldquoSo, so sad, Irsquom so lucky that our council helped me out to get my flat after mum passed, otherwise Irsquod probably be doing this with my cat, canrsquot believe how people think this is acceptable! Wrong on so many levels, I hope he and his dog get the help they need.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoFor reasons of confidentiality, we cannot go into detail on inidual cases.ldquoIn general, for someone to be eligible to take over a tenancy, we have to have been told that that person has been living at the address in question as their principal or only home for a period of at least  months with a requirement to also noty us at the point they become resident in line with Scottish Government guidelines.ldquoIn terms of temporary accommodation, it is sometimes not possible to accommodate pets, so a pet owner would have to find alternative temporary care.ldquoOur officers always strive to find a suitable solution to anyone finding themselves homeless but, due to the increasingly high demand for social housing and the pressure on our housing service, it is not always possible to make an offer that meets someonersquos preferences in full, especially when we are looking at temporary solutions.

title: independence-campaigner-jonathan-shafi-speaking-group-meeting
story: Jonathan Shafi will speak following Yes Dunbarrsquos annual general meeting in the townrsquos Bleachingfield Centre.The meeting gets under way at .pm and Mr Shafi will speak on the topic of lsquoAfter the Growth Commission: Preparing the case for independencersquo.Yes Dunbar is a non-party campaign group making the case for an independent Scotland.Some members have links to political partiesbut many are independence supporters with no party affiliation.To attend the meeting, register at www.yesdunbar.eventbrite before .pm tomorrow.

title: paul-mclennan-msps-praise-leuchie-houses-efforts
story: Staff and volunteers at respite charity Leuchie House, on the outskirts of North Berwick, were lauded for their work during a recent visit by Paul McLennan, who said the facility had ldquoimproved the lives of thousands of people with MS and other neurological conditions. It provides dedicated support through respite breaks, as well as breaks for carers.Leuchie is celebrating  years of becoming an independent charity this year with a fundraising campaign called lsquoHare to Stay!rsquo which aims to raise funds to ensure the charity can continue to offer support to families long into the future.This includes The Big Hare Trail, run in partnership with Wild in Art, which has seen  decorated hares dotted around the North Berwick area since July.They are set to be auctioned off tomorrowto raise money for Leuchie. with Leuchie House CEO Mark Bevan during his visit to the respite centre" alt"East Lothian Courier: Paul McLennanwith Leuchie House CEO Mark Bevan during his visit to the respite centre" class"editor-image"Paul McLennanwith Leuchie House CEO Mark Bevan during his visit to the respite centreOn his recent visit, Mr McLennan said: ldquoIt was great to visit Leuchie House to hear about the work they do to provide people living with multiple sclerosis, Parkinsonrsquos, motor neurone disease and stroke and their families from across the country with much-needed support.ldquoLeuchie House has been a real leline for hundreds of families in the  years since becoming an independent charity thanks to the community-led lsquoSave Leuchiersquo campaign.ldquoSince then, staff and volunteers have continued to provide support that has improved the lives of thousands of people with MS and other neurological conditions.ldquoThe Big Hare trail is an excellent way to say thank you to the local community for its continuous support.I was delighted to see one of the hares during my visit.

title: hare-trail-creations-going-hammer-leuchie-house
story: The auction, hosted by broadcaster Glenn Campbell, takes place at the Marine Hotel from .pm. Auctioneer May Mathews, who works with Bonhams in Scotland, will get the bidding under way from pm.The hare trail has seen  six-foot hare sculptures placed in ious locations around North Berwick and Dirleton over the past  weeks.Each hare was commissioned by a local business or charity and decorated by a selected local artist.The trail was created to celebrate Leuchiersquos th anniversary of becoming an independent charity.But as the trail draws to a close, each sculpture will go under the hammer to raise funds for the respite centre. Each lot is expected to fetch in excess of pound,.One of the most popular statues was lsquoHare Tae Golfrsquo at the townrsquos West Links, having earlier made a cameo at The Renaissance for the abrdn Scottish Open in July. Members at both venues are now lining up bids for Chris Rutterfordrsquos creation, with The Renaissance Club taking pledges from members ahead of a bid at the auction.Tantallon and North Berwick Golf Clubs are also bidding to keep the hare and are fast approaching pound, in donations to support a bid.Yvonne Keeling, who set up the West Links campaign page, said: ldquoWe have very much enjoyed the presence of the golfing hare this summer. Every day, people gathered there for photographs and he has become quite a talking point. This has helped to raise awareness of Leuchie House and the wonderful work that they do.Meanwhile, the mum of one artist is fundraising to keep her daughterrsquos artwork on public display.Abbie Heriott with mum Kirsty and the statue she paintedAbbie Herriot grew up in North Berwick and has fond memories of visiting both the Scottish Seabird Centre and Leuchie House as a child, the visits providing inspiration for her gannet and puffin lsquoOcean Viewrsquo design. Her story recently appeared in the Courier.Her mum Kirsty, who has already raised more than pound, on a JustGiving page, said: ldquoWhat started as half a joke that I would need to save hard to try and win it when it went to auction has turned into a reality, with the help of hard work and help from family and friends.ldquoWe are bidding for the community. We would much rather have Abbiersquos hare in North Berwick, where we can all still see it and visit, than in some private collection.Leuchie House is also hoping to put in a bid to seea hare or two can be secured for the respite centre and its new fully accessible holiday home in Dirleton, Denis Duncan House. Nearly pound, has been raised.And therersquos a final twist in the tale.A blank hare will be auctioned at the end, which might give any disappointed bidders the opportunity to have another shot at a hare.Some of the Big Hare Trail artists have agreed to create a bespoke design for the successful bidder.Lana Bambridge, head of fundraising and development for Leuchie House, said: ldquoWersquore pleased that the hares have captured the hearts of the local community and would love to see a few remain nearby for the continued enjoyment of local families and visitors.ldquoEvery penny raised from the auction will help us to continue to support families who are in desperate need of a break from caring, especially in the wake of the pandemic.

title: fundraising-help-man-realise-american-dream
story: John McGrogan, , who lives in Prestonpans, met Hailey, his American girlfriend of three years, on Twitter and is now hoping to make a permanent move Stateside to join her in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, where she is studying.He is busy raising funds to start his new le in the US through his hobby of livestreaming worldwide on his Facebook page Running Crutches, saying: ldquoIt is a great creative outlet and I can entertain thousands of people at the press of a button.John provides the free entertainment on Facebook gaming streams and is raising funds via PayPal, adding: ldquoI let people knowthey want to support my move to America and want to help fund it to press the donation link in the description of all my streams.ldquoI donrsquot ask people to donate ndash I let people decidethey want to themselves.ldquoI donrsquot have a minimum amount that can be given because every penny truly does count.He said that his streams were not pointed towards a specic audience, adding: ldquoI do mainly [combat game]Warzone and do a lot within the realms of that game, whether it be playing competitive matches and tournaments.ldquoI do a lot of challenge streams where I get my viewers to set me challenges and parameters that I use in the games. I would describe them as ied but specic to Warzone.John, who is originally from Eskview in Musselburgh and is a former Campie Primary School pupil, was diagnosed with osteosarcoma ndash bone cancer ndash just above his knee at the age of  while he was a pupil at Musselburgh Grammar School and had to leave in the middle of his fourth year.He said that he replaced classes with attending chemotherapy appointments and surgery.ldquoIt was only after the first few weeks where it reality hit and the effects of the chemo kicked in that I realised le would never be the same again, he said.ldquoI had three dferent types of chemo and a lot of surgeries that lasted until .ldquoI like to call my last cancer surgery my amputation because that was the end of the leg that held the tumour.ldquoI still have immense phantom pains from the removal of the limb and have acute pain in the stump that was left, so every day it feels like Irsquom still having this battle with cancer that I thought would finish back then.John has a prosthetic leg and will start to walk on it again once the pain from his surgeries has subsided. He is unable to work at present.John has not seen Hailey for more than  days due to borders in America being closed.He is hoping he can raise enough funds to cover the cost of his move to the ldquoland of opportunity, including visas, and is also eventually hoping to get his own house and American citizenship.John said: ldquoThe Covid- pandemic in itself wouldnrsquot have been a problem for me.ldquoIrsquom fully vaccinated and have never had the disease.ldquoThe only thing that stopped us was the US travel ban, which has had the country closed for almost two years now.John, who lives with his parents and two brothers, added: ldquoHaving cancer really put things into perspective. I canrsquot just sit around and not do the things I dream about in le ndash I just have got to go for it. The only thing holding me back is the cost but, once I get through this first gate, it should be smooth sailing.His Facebook page is facebook RunningCrutches

title: medical-centre-staff-celebrated-efforts-coronavirus
story: The Rotary Club of Dunbar presented the Community Service Award to the staff at the three surgeries earlier this summer.The award was to recognise their dedication to the community throughout the pandemic.The presentation of the award, which has previously been won by Graham Adams, Kirsty McLuckie and the Rev Laurence Twaddle, had been delayed due to the ious lockdowns.Andrew Brown, previous president of the Rotary Club, and Elaine OrsquoBrien were on hand to present the Community Salver.

title: dad-sister-running-marathon-duncan-mcleans-memory
story: Iain McLean and daughter Annabel will pound the streets during the London Marathon on Sunday alongside thousands of other runners.The duo are representing the Brain Tumour Charity, following the death of Duncan McLean five years ago.The former Gullane Primary School and Musselburghrsquos Loretto School pupil died from a glioblastoma multormebrain tumour in February  ndash just three days after he was admitted to hospital with severe headaches.Sixty-year-old Iain told the Courier that Duncan had always wanted to complete a marathon.Now, Duncanrsquos dad and -year-old sister Annabel will take on the .-mile race in his memory.Iain, who lives in Gullane, said: ldquoIt has kept us doing the ious fundraising things and working with the charity.ldquoIt is good for us to keep people thinking about Duncan and doing public things rather than just cowering away in a darkened room.ldquoIt is five years on but it is still tough, to be honest.Iain had been due to line up in London last April but the event was cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic.The famous race was rescheduled for October but, due to the pandemic, it was only elite runners taking on the challenge.Now, Iain will be joined by his daughter, who is a doctor in Glasgow, in representing the charity.Training started in November  and Iain was now looking forward to the race getting under way and seeing the sights broadcast to millions on the BBC.He said: ldquoThe landmarks will be fantastic.ldquoIt is great and I am looking forward to it.ldquoWe are going to have a nice weekend in London, my we is coming down to support us and we are meeting with other people.To support Iain and Annabel, go to justgiving fundraising iain-mclean

title: haddington-corn-exchange-may-not-reopen-2022
story: An pound, refurbishment of Haddingtonrsquos Corn Exchange was due to start in February .That was delayed due to ldquofurther intrusive survey work and the refurbishment was then further hampered by the coronavirus pandemic.Now, community councillors have been told that the prominent Court Street building might not reopen until next year.Fiona McEwan, secretary of Haddington and District Community Council, discussed the issue at the grouprsquos virtual meeting.She said: ldquoI spoke to [East Lothian] Council and there is still snagging work getting done.ldquoI cannot see it being open before November. I was told it is more likely to be the beginning of next year before it starts getting rented out.The venue, which has hosted everything from concerts by the likes of Fish and The Proclaimers to blood donor sessions, charity fundraisers and a iety of community organisations, dates back to .Haddington Festival, which has been cancelled for the last two years, is usually based in the building, which is also used by the community council during the festive period.The refurbishment, which has resulted in the main hall being out of use for more than two years, involved new roof lights being installed in the main hall, as well as roof repairs and timber flooring being replaced.A new storage area, new kitchen and additional toilets have also been created, with minor decoration of the building to be carried out.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council confirmed that there was still minor work, including polishing and painting, being carried out in the building.But one of the main problems was still the coronavirus pandemic, despite the recent relaxing of restrictions.The spokeswoman said: ldquoThe main issue, in common with other public buildings, is a lack of staff to maintain and clean the buildings prior to use and afterwards.ldquoOur facilities management resources are very stretched just now and cleaning staff in particular are prioritising statutory services such as schools.ldquoAn interesting aside to this is the impact within the councilrsquos own buildings, as we currently have a number of toilets and shared kitchen areas in John Muir House reduced for staff to access to provide cleaning support where.

title: ormiston-teenager-shares-gaelic-experiences-television-show
story: Tawana Maramba , who lives on Wildflower Crescent, appears in Trusadh: Afro-Gagraveidheil ndash Afro-Gaels, a documentary that follows Cass Ezeji, a Gaelic-speaking singer with Scottish and Nigerian roots.Throughout the programme, Cass explores her relationship with Gaelic culture and history.She meets Gaelic speakers of African and Caribbean descent to discuss how they connect to the language and culture while also talking to experts to uncover the Gaelrsquos role in the slave trade.Tawana, , discusses her education at a Gaelic school and how she enjoys singing in Gaelic. She also teaches Gaelic singing.Tawanarsquos parents are from Zimbabwe and have taught her the Shona language, a Bantu language of the Shona people of Zimbabwe.Tawana was born in Edinburgh, moving to Ormiston two years ago. She also has a strong connection to Zimbabwe culture.She attended Tollcross Primary School in Edinburgh, which offered the only Gaelic medium primary education in Edinburgh and the Lothians.Tawana stayed there until a new Gaelic primary school opened in Bonnington, Leith, called Bun-sgoil Taobh na Pagraveirce.Afterwards, she attended James Gillespiersquos High School, also in Edinburgh.Tawana runs an after-school club in Bun-sgoil Taobh na Pagraveirce, teaching Gaelic to pupils.She said: ldquoI feel some people react like: lsquoOh, you speak Gaelic !rsquo But Irsquom quite proud of that.ldquoIt plays a huge part in my le. There are lots of things I wouldnrsquot be doingit wasnrsquot for Gaelic. Irsquom grateful that I can speak Gaelic.Trusadh: Afro-Gagraveidheil ndash Afro-Gaels airs on BBC ALBA on Monday at pm and will be available on BBC iPlayer for  days.

title: new-aldi-supermarket-opens-haddington-retail-park
story: The supermarket, which has closed its branch on the townrsquos Whittingehame Drive, opened at Haddington Retail Park this morning .Customers were welcomed inside the new store, which joins Costa Coffee and The Food Warehouse in the retail park, shortly after am.The Gateside Commerce Park storewill be run by store manager Darren Ross, along with a team of  colleagues from the local community.In celebration, Team GB silver medallist Gemma Gibbons gave away complimentary bags of fresh fruit and vegetables from Aldirsquos famous Super  range to the first  customers in the queue, before delivering anassembly for pupils at Haddington Primary School as part of the supermarketrsquos initiative,Get Set to Eat Freshndash which has already inspired over . million school children aged - years to learn more about the benefits of cooking fresh, healthy food with their families.In addition, Aldi Haddington offered pupils at the local primary school the opportunity to win a pound gt voucher to spend at the new store.Children atHaddington Primary Schoolwere tasked with creating a poster to show what healthy eating means to them.Darren Ross said: ldquoItrsquos been a wonderful morning here at the opening of Aldi Haddington."It was lovely to welcome our new customers into store, and I look forward to meeting more of the community in the coming weeks."Irsquom also thrilled that wersquove been able to support Haddington Primary School through our partnership with Team GB.Gemma Gibbons added: ldquoIrsquove had a fantastic time opening the new Aldi store here in Haddington."It was an honour to officially open the store and welcome customers inside for the first time.ldquoIt was great to speak with the children at Haddington Primary School about the importance of eating healthily and how it can be fun to plan and prepare meals as a family."Hopefully, Irsquove also managed to inspire the pupils to keep active and try dferent sports.The new Aldi store is calling on local charities and food banks in Haddington to register with Neighbourly, a community engagement  that links businesses to charitable organisations in the local community.Local charities that register will be able to collect surplus food and perishable products, such as fruit, vegetables and baked goods, up to seven days a week.Any charities in the area that would like to partner up with the new Aldi store should emailaldi@neighbourly.Home Bargains isset to open in the retail park, on Haddingtonrsquos western edge, on October .

title: east-lothians-first-crematorium-set-approved-old-craighall
story: Crematorium operators Westerleigh Grouprsquos plans for a new facility aim to ensure that funeral corteges do not have to take more than  minutes to reach their final destination.And they say that their plans for East Lothian will mean grieving families no longer face the ldquounacceptable delays which can be caused travelling to Edinburgh in congested traffic.In their statement supporting the countyrsquos need for the facility, the group said: ldquoLocal residentsare required to travel into Edinburgh, using the congested road network, in order to attend funeral services of their loved ones.ldquoSuchunpredictable journeys, on what is already a stressful day, are unacceptable.ldquoA new crematorium in this location will serve c., people as their closest crematorium and give c., the choice of a new, modern crematorium within a -minute funeral cortegravegedrive time.ldquoResidents of East Lothian and the surroundingcommunities would benefit from a modern facility that is closer totheir doorsteps.Planners have recommended the crematorium plans for the site, which is to the north of Old Craighall village, are approved when they go before councillors next week.In their report to elected members, planners said: ldquoThe applicant advises that office and cremation hours would be am to pm butinforms that cremations can sometimes go over : hours in busy periods, for instance a cold winter or a pandemic, when deaths are higher.ldquoAn ornamental garden, memorial garden and lsquoparklandrsquo feature would be formed around the crematorium building, with paths through them.ldquoWoodland tree and hedgerow planting is proposed to be undertaken around the perimeter of the site and within the site itself would betree and hedge planting and areas of amenity grasslands.Scotland has the lowest rate of cremations in the UK, with an estimated  percent of funerals cremations however, Westlerigh Group suggests this is down to a lack of facilities rather than choice.And the company says it is accepted in the industry that the average cortegravegetime for a funeral from the deceased personrsquos home to service should be no more than  minutes.Westerleigh Group says there are on average about , deaths in East Lothian every year.In their case for the new facility, they said: ldquoThere are vast areas within East Lothian Council that are not served within a benchmark -minute cortegravegedrive time of an existing crematoria.ldquoAll residents of East Lothian Council currently have to travel out of district, and the majorityhave to travel into Edinburgh for their nearest crematorium.ldquoThis often involves having to endure signicant delays to their journeys due to traffic build up on the City Bypass, the A and or local road networks into Edinburgh.ldquoThis causes the bereaved additional stress anda very poor qualitative experience.The committee will discuss the plans at a virtual meeting next week.

title: tributes-paid-local-radio-pioneer
story: One of the leading figures of the Scottish radio industry, he started his career in newspapers, including a spell with The Haddingtonshire Courier and the Daily Mail.He went on to become the first employee at Radio Clyde in , when he was appointed to set up and lead its news team. Just two years later, he moved to the east as head of news at Radio Forth to drive the new stationrsquos launch.Tom always considered himself a reporter, and once said: ldquoItrsquos what goes on in between the records that makes a station unique. Itrsquos all about whatrsquos going on in the area, cementing your roots in the community, with something for everyone and telling them yoursquore doing it.An illustration of that thinking came in winter , which saw much of Forthrsquos broadcast area come to a standstill after a sudden blizzard.Tom, who lived just outside Pencaitland, launched a week of emergency planned billed lsquoSnowlinersquo to help people in the community who had become stranded or were facing other dficulties caused by the weather, demonstrating the role that independent local radiocould play.He went on to become programme director, overseeing the creation of Forth  on FM and Forth  on AM, before taking over as managing director.He retired through ill health in .Luisa Cairns, then the newsroom secretary at Forth, said: ldquoIrsquom really shocked. I have too many memories of him to think of only one. Probably, like most othersrsquo recollections of him, I would say he was a very big character, kind, fair, meticulous and funny.John Collins wrote on Facebook: ldquoRIP Tom Steele. One of the ILR originals who launched Clyde and then Forth.ldquoHe was a man who was a bit mad, a bit scary and a bit perfect in equal measure. He convinced me it was OK to take a  per cent pay cut to join Forth.ldquoHe was a risk taker and a legend.Graham Bryce, chief operating officer of Bauer Media, which now owns Forth, said: ldquoTom was one of the driving forces behind Radio Forth as he was passionate about radio and doing the best for our listeners and the local area.ldquoLocal radio was very new in the UK at the time and Tom was at the forefront of the industry, which was recognised by the many awards and accolades he won over the years.

title: tesco-fresh-bid-avoid-paying-400k-interest-contributions-schooling-musselburgh
story: The food chain is appealing to Scottish Ministers to step in after East Lothian Council billed it four months afterconstruction started on  new homes on land formerly owned by the firm.Tesco had argued that it no longer had to pay the pound, educationcontribution tied to the new housing as it was no longer the owner of the land.But it lost its argument and an appeal against the decision was ruled lsquounlawfulrsquo.After being told it had to pay the bill, Tesco then applied to change the terms of the repaymentso it did not have to pay until the last house was completed rather than at the start of the development as previously agreed.The request was refused by the local authority, which now wants the bill paid with interest backdated to last year.The supermarket chain has now lodged an appeal with Scottish Ministers, asking them to overturn the councilrsquos decision so it can pay the bill at the end of the development and avoid the interest.East Lothian Council has argued that Tesco is getting off lightly after the deal over the land at its former store site at Olivebank was signed  years ago.They said thata similar deal was struck today, the contribution request would be closer to pound,.And they warned that a delay to the payment being made could ldquosignicantly impact ongoing projects to provide a new secondary school in Wallyford and extend Musselburgh Grammar School.Under planning legislation, local authorities can ask housing developers to pay a proportion of money towards schooling to counteract the additional number of families moving into their homes.Appealing against paying the contribution, Tesco argued: ldquoThis transactiontook place over a decade ago and the land of the residential developmentsite is not owned by Tesco.Rejecting Tescorsquos application, planning officers warned that Tesco was liable for interest rates of four per cent above the Bank of Scotland rate on the outstanding payment and the longer they took to pay, the more the value of the contribution was eroded by cost increases.They added that it would set a precedent for future infrastructure contributions which could put them at risk.The appeal has been lodged with the Scottish GovernmentReporters.

title: virgin-money-scottish-branch-closing
story: The former Clydesdale Bank branches are located across Scotland, with  more due to shut UK-wide from early next year.According to the bank, all the branches closing are located less than a third of a mile away from the nearest post office, although some people will be considerably further from another Virgin Money.The closures are expected to impact around  workers in Scotland, with the bank saying it will find alternative roles where possible.However, it has not ruled out potential redundancies.Here are the  branches closing in Scotland...The  Virgin Money branches closing in early  in Scotland are:For people using the Portree branch, their nearest branchwill now be over  mile away in Fort William.Unite industrial officerDebbie Hutchings deemed the closures "shameful", adding:"The announcement will disproportionately impact on workers and communities across Scotland."Island communities from Portree to rural towns such as Wick are going to be left behind by Virgin Money."Our nations town centres, from Cumbernauld to Musselburgh, will be further hollowed out as fewer people will come into townthere is no bank branch."

title: covid-passport-paper-copy-get-vaccine-passport-paper-form
story: Many people will choose to use theNHS Scotland Covid Status App which can be scanned to accessnightclubs, indoor live events with + people unseated, outdoor live events with + peopleunseated and any event with ,+ people.However,you dont have a smartphone and cant access a digital copy of your vaccine status, dont worry - you can order a paper copy online or on the phone.Heres how to order a paper copy of your vaccine passport...You can order a paper copy of your vaccine passport via your vaccine portal.To access your vaccine portal, you must register an account using your unique username.Your unique username can be found inthe letter, email or text youwere sent inviting you to attend your vaccine appointments.Once you have created an account, status of your vaccination can be found by selecting "vaccination status".On the bottom of the page, you can select "request a paper copy", which could take up to -days to arrive by post.Alternatively, you can order a paper copy by phoningthe specially designated Covid status helpline on  , open from am-pm every day.This paper copy, like theNHS Scotland Covid Status App, can be used for international travel and will include barcodes which can be scanned by venues.These barcodes areuneditable and usespecial ink to prevent forgery.Find out how to download theNHS Scotland Covid Status App here.

title: travel-rules-scotland-new-testing-rules-international-travel-uk
